story:
The Project

The Expatriate is a one man show being developed by University of the Arts students James Whittall and Aria Velz, and alumnus Lauren Tuvell. Chronicling the Ernest Hemingway of the 1920s during his days in Paris, reflecting on his life and the Lost Generation of Expatriates, the show seeks to provide a unique level of audience/performer interaction. It brings audiences face to face with Hemingway, perhaps even to act as dramatic influence...

The Expatriate will be performed April 3rd through the 6th, 2014 in the Laurie Beechman Cabaret, downstairs at the Arts Bank on Broad and South Streets.

What We Need & What You Get

We need $500 to pay our hard working band and director!

In return, you'll get exclusive access to journals and videos of our creative process, keepsakes from the show, plus, the added benefit of being credited in the program AND an invitation to our closed dress rehearsal!

No amount is too small in helping to ensure these artists are compensated for providing you the most quality entertainment they can. Please consider making a donation to help support this team of up-and-comers in the Philly theatre scene.
story_txt:
The Project
The Expatriate is a one man show being developed by University of the Arts students James Whittall and Aria Velz, and alumnus Lauren Tuvell. Chronicling the Ernest Hemingway of the 1920s during his days in Paris, reflecting on his life and the Lost Generation of Expatriates, the show seeks to provide a unique level of audience/performer interaction. It brings audiences face to face with Hemingway, perhaps even to act as dramatic influence...The Expatriate will be performed April 3rd through the 6th, 2014 in the Laurie Beechman Cabaret, downstairs at the Arts Bank on Broad and South Streets.What We Need & What You GetWe need $500 to pay our hard working band and director! In return, you'll get exclusive access to journals and videos of our creative process, keepsakes from the show, plus, the added benefit of being credited in the program AND an invitation to our closed dress rehearsal!No amount is too small in helping to ensure these artists are compensated for providing you the most quality entertainment they can. Please consider making a donation to help support this team of up-and-comers in the Philly theatre scene.

story:
Hello everyone,

my name is Shay Kuebler and I've been an independent dancer, performer and choreographer in Vancouver for the past 8 years. I come from a background in martial arts and theatre, which lead to a diverse background in dance. My performance works reflect a theatrical sensibility and raw physicality, which is formed around projection, live sound, interactive technology and other elements. All in attempts to bring the viewer further into the experience and purpose of the performance work. Currently, my creative work is beginning to reach out of the local community and tour nationally and internationally. The infrastructure I have in place as an individual artist is not able to maintain the growth of my work, so I'm now at the beginning stages of opening an arts society to further support my work. With the genesis of the arts society, I will be able to expand my art form and develop what I'm creating further, but I need your assistance with the initial growth of this company.

I have great belief in my work and its ability to reach diverse audiences. I've witnessed this through the success of touring and performing over the past 6 years, and believe that I'm creating unique work that is not only integral to my artistry but is accessible and is creating a larger audience for dance and physical performance. I strive to make a theatre experience that is captivating, enriching and stimulates your own instigation towards creativity and what makes you passionate. I thank you for your time in reading these words and checking out the video. Throw this out on facebook, instagram, banagrams, youtube or on paper. Any assistance is welcome, so feel free to spread this campaign - if the spirit grabs you. 

Sincerely,

Shay Kuebler

Please visit www.shaykuebler.com for further information on my work and on the touring project KAROSHI. 

“...it so fully embodied entertainment and artistry at such high levels...” – Vancouver Weekly

All photo credits - David Cooper Photography 

Shay Kuebler Radical System Arts Society 

SKRSA aims to expand the art of physical performance through dance, martial arts, theatre, music and other forms, and utilize film and stage as mediums to promote, disseminate and enhance performance art. Blending multiple genres of art, the society pushes the boundaries of physical performance and is constantly researching and redeveloping its artistic form to reach new audiences and further engage followers to physical performance. Through continued research, intensive training and discovery, the society focuses strength on expansion, education, public appreciation and collaboration with new methodologies and ideologies. Believing that all techniques and practices, when used in an instinctive manner, can reinforce each other and create a greater potential in the art of physical performance. The goal of the company is to create a visceral, risk-taking physicality and give it precision, detail and structure. Balancing the raw and unstructured with the precise and exact, then focusing these accelerated and ambitious forms with a theatrical sensibility. Creating a greater capacity to experiment and delve into the furthest edges of choreographic innovation and physical performance.

"... cleverly imaginative as it is physically pummeling." - Georgia Straight

Shay Kuebler 

was born and raised in Sherwood Park, Alberta, Shay's foundation in arts began with Martial Arts and Theatre at the age of 5. With this early development, he has developed a multi-disciplinary background in martial forms, dance techniques, music and theatre. Shay has been an independent dance artist in the city of Vancouver and Montreal for the past 8 years. Along with his successes as a collaborator and co-director, he has had the honor of performing and creating his own work for Canadian and international arts festivals and dance companies. With a foundation in the martial arts, he is constantly searching for how physical performance can be finely tuned yet retain an instinctual and raw quality. As a dance artist, whose professional performing and choreographic career has spanned the disciplines of  tap, hip hop, neo-classical ballet and contemporary dance, Shay also looks at how all techniques can reinforce and strengthen each other. That technique, when used in an instinctive manner, can be integrated into any other form of art. Creating cross-disciplinary works that create a greater potential and capacity for each form. 

The society will be aiming to gain sponsorship from a charitable organization and will look to offer charitable tax receipts upon request. 


Upcoming Activity and Future Projects

MiBC Touring

Wednesday, April 2nd – Friday, April 4th - Burnaby – Shadbolt Centre for The Arts http://www.burnaby.ca/Things-To-Do/Arts-and-Heritage/Shadbolt-Centre-for-the-Arts.html

Monday, April 7th - Saltspring Island – Artspring http://artspring.ca

Thursday, April 10th - Kelowna – Rotary Centre for The Arts http://www.rotarycentreforthearts.com

Saturday, April 12th - Vernon – Vernon and District Performing Arts Centre http://www.ticketseller.ca

Wednesday, April 16th - Nelson – Capitol Theatre http://www.capitoltheatre.bc.ca

Saturday, April 19th - Smithers – Bulkley Valley Concert Association http://www.bvartscouncil.com

For more information visit http://www.madeinbc.org

Future Projects:

assisting creation and performance of GRIT - Tramway Theatre - Glasgow, Scotland  World Premiere, June 2014

GLORY - World premiere for the winter of 2014/2015, Choreographed and Directed by Shay Kuebler 

Official Trailer: https://vimeo.com/88623996

story:
Edit 5/17/14: I've added a new perk - $100 gets you 1 full piece and 2 postcards!

Hi guys!

   My name is Libbi Murray, part of the creative team working under the aegis of Adivisk Arts, and the solo artist behind the name [im]Perfect Lines. 

   My art is specifically very geometric in nature, consisting of lines to form patterns and shapes. My inspirations range from traditional tribal patterns to Amish quilts to architecture. I firmly believe in handmade art, creating everything with my own two hands and a pen and paper, with the occasional ruler. I do not do any digital art, although I do digitize it to post online, as you can see below in the perks section. 

   Now, I can hear you thinking, "Well, I've never heard of [im]Perfect Lines!" and there are a few reasons why:

   Reason number one being that I suffer from as-of-yet incurable chronic pain disease called fibromyalgia, with all the terrible co-existing conditions, and an undetermined form of arthritis. These both mean that, while somewhat manageable, it's basically impossible for me to work a normal job. That's why I am attempting to follow my dream of being a self-sustaining, self-supporting artist and writer.

   Reason number two being that, while I have all the time in the world to dedicate to my art, I don't have the money or resources to grow my dream beyond a Tumblr blog. Supplies dwindle fast, and without a job or steady income, are very difficult to come by. My art is very limited by what supplies I do have, and how much of them I want to use on a single project.

   So, I'm here, hoping to get some support and love and donations from fellow artists, dreamers, and/or all around decent human beings!

This is what you'd be funding:   

   > Normal artist-y type supplies - everything from paper to pens and pencils to canvas and fixatives. I want to see if I can branch out, so there would be things like blank tiles, mugs, or decorative boxes purchased also.

   > A couple of more specific things, such as a magnifier for small detailing and a larger table [instead of a wooden dinner tray] to work on.

   > Some things to help with the fibromyalgia pain plus the strain of working long hours on art - pain relieving cream, a heated neck and shoulder wrap, a hand brace, etc - so I can produce both more and better quality art.

   > A decent camera to take not-awful pictures of my artwork that is too big to fit in my scanner while I save up for a huge industrial scanner.

   > A website, to put all the amazing art I can accomplish with the above items into the world and more easily manage my online art life. While Adivisk Arts focuses on online work and graphic design and building websites, domain names and hosting aren't free.

   > A small amount to live on and pay bills with while I am on my way to building my own little empire [muahahaha] and some money to give my absolutely wonderful parents for helping me out with a place to live during these difficult times.

This is what you'd be getting: (sample colors shown)



$10 gets you 2 postcard sized (4" x 6") pieces. Please choose any TWO from the postcards shown above and they will be done in the color scheme(s) of your choice.

$25 gets you 5 postcard sized (4" x 6") pieces. Please choose any FIVE from the postcards shown above and they will be done in the color scheme(s) of your choice.

$50 gets you 1 full sized (8.5" x 11") piece. Please choose ONE from the pieces shown below and it will be done in the color scheme of your choice.

$150 gets you both full sized (8.5" x 11") pieces and 2 postcard sized (4" x 6") pieces - please choose any TWO from the postcards shown above - and they will be done in the color scheme(s) of your choice.





Extra Information:

   Depending on how well this campaign goes, I may add extra perks as time goes on.

   Please Remember: Every single piece that I create is done 100% by hand. I spend hours, days, weeks, or even months on a single project. So much hard work goes into my creations. PLEASE do not upload them and share them, because everything I do takes a lot of time and effort. They each will eventually get put up on my website and we will go from there.

   Also, none of the pieces will be framed, since that would cost waaay too much to ship, and that way you can choose the best way for you to display it! But if you absolutely must have it framed before I send it out, please add an extra $10 to your donation and we will hash out the details at the end of the campaign.

   And since shipping isn't free, ALL ITEMS will be shipped AFTER the campaign ends and I receive the funds. Thank you for your patience and understanding.

   And Finally: Thank you so much for checking out my campaign! I hope some of you will donate, but if you can't [and I shall understand] *PLEASE* spread the word! Even if I don't make my goal, I have a flexible funding campaign and whatever money I raise will go towards realizing my dream!

   EDIT: Please let me know which designs you want and  what your color preference is - send me a message or leave a comment!

story:
About this project

The Acoustic SpokenWord Cafe is our incubator for enriching the life of our city and the lives of its artists.

 

Who we are

Peace and blessings to you and your families from the Coordinating Council of the Three Rivers Institute of Afrikan Art & Culture, TRIAAC. We're a collective of artists and volunteers working to sustain the Acoustic SpokenWord Café. TRIAAC is a multigenerational, cultural community strengthening identity through the arts, and the Acoustic SpokenWord Café is our incubator for enriching the life of our city and the lives of its artists.

Four seasons ago, we opened the Café doors because there was no other city venue where folks could hear spokenword or acoustic music. Every other venue was simply a watering hole where artists were the background noise for raucous voices and clinking glasses.

TRIAAC wanted to change that. We know that artists have critical messages for us, and we wanted them to be heard. So we opened our doors on faith that the community would come to a venue where art was the real focus. We were right! Featuring seasoned artists, new talent, an Open Mic at each Café, and a $5 admission charge, we've grown from an average 15 patrons two years ago, to 35 at the end of our third season. We'll grow that average to 50 in a house that seats 65 by the end of our fourth season.

 

How you can help

With a small grant from our local Arts agency last year, we were able to give artists a small stipend in appreciation and support of their work. That grant is no more and to continue to grow we now need your help!

By the end of September we must raise $7500 to cover the season’s artist stipends, operational costs and promotions. $4900 of that will go to artist fees. Another $1200 will go to advertising and promotions, and operations and supplies will consume the $1400 balance.

 

We know these are hard times and that you may not be able to give financially. But please tell your friends; talk us up in your social spaces, help us to help artists secure the people's space downtown.

 

What we have to give

We have a few perks to offer you, but we know this is not really about the perks (our precious CDs and T-shirts). No! This is about planting and sustaining the people's art in the downtown of Indiana's second largest city. This art grows from the lives of the people and is vital to the downtown growth of our city.

Thank you, and we give you our word that we will grow your contributions into sustaining funds for the Acoustic SpokenWord Cafe!

Peace and blessings.

story:
Iowa to Munich

  • I'm a full time artist based in Iowa City, IA.
  • I've spent the last couple of years evolving toward new work loosely under the banner of "animal/vegetable/mineral"
  • Munich Jewellery Week is the largest international venue for contemporary jewelry.
  • Getting to share this new work with the international community at MJW is very exciting!
  • The shop I will be exhibiting in, Louloute, will offer a unique setting to create an installation for this work.

I'm Broke, but I Can't Miss This Opportunity

  • Lodging at Pension Belo Sono for $378.98 for March 11-18. This location is ideal not just because of the price, but because it is on Gollierstraße, right across from Louloute!
  • There is a rental fee for the venue  of about 350€ (excl. VAT) which will be between $450 and $500 (US) depending upon where exchange rates are by the time I get there.
  • The travel costs to Munich are about $1100, with the potential for luggage fees given all that I need to bring with me.
  • I would like to live on more than peanut butter for the week if possible.
  • Having done a fundraiser before, I've learned that it isn't so smart to make the perks overlap with the work of the project. This time I'm fully embracing the potential of swag, and with the help of Ben Smasher, we will be producing a variety of merchandise with peculiar images generated from this work.
  • These funds will go toward keeping me from digging myself even deeper in credit card debt!

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

  • I know my work isn't exactly everyone's cup of tea, but I am always happy to find the folks it really resonates with. 
  • Being based in Iowa City, many people only experience my work in the form of digital images. However, when I get the opportunity to share them in person, I think it is so much more resonant.
  • This is the third time I've turned to crowdfunding to complete a project, having used it once before to get to SIERAAD with Ben as my assistant, and before that to bring a group of 10 US jewelry makers to SIERAAD as well. 
  • Surviving as a full time artist is filled with risk. The support and encouragement I've gotten over the years is invaluable. This next opportunity feels especially exciting given both the platform, and where I am at in my practice.

Why Do I (And All Artists) Need Financial Support?

It is not easy surviving as a full time artist. Very few make it a full time profession, and most of those are often subsidized from personal wealth. Americans are acclimated to both painfully low wages and cheap consumer goods, so we have limited options for a collecting public. Additionally, other arts funding is more scarce, and directed at work that has the least chance of commercial viability. Essentially, making weird objects that are both functional and labeled "jewelry", but which are challenging in many ways, makes life hard for all of us art jewelry makers.

I've spent the last seven years trying different fairs in different locations hoping to hone in on who, exactly, my work is most appealing to. Last year, bolstered by the volume of work I've been producing, I tried to juggle multiple fairs on a schedule that I know many other artists manage well, or even exceed. Though I met many amazing people, and I'm glad I got to share the work in person as it always makes for a deeper connection, the end result left me in rough shape. Overall, I'm always the weird kid at fairs, and it is a very draining experience. I pushed myself too hard trying to off-set the expenses, juggled workshops to subsidize, did a very bad job at taking care of myself, and still ended up in the red and worse for wear physically. I want to make this exhibition work, but I don't want to spend the rest of 2019 wondering how to survive because of it. Any help with this is deeply appreciated!

Other Ways You Can Help

I know a lot of you reading this are artists/makers as I am. I wouldn't have made it this far without the support of other artists. However, I know that means many of you are in the same place I am: trying to sustain a creative life on slim margins. If you can't support me right now, I understand. There have been times when I had extra money to help a friend's project, and there have been times when I had nothing to spare. Just help me share this, get the word out, and if you're coming to Munich in March, please come by and say hello!

/

More Info About My Work/This Series

Polyphonous: animal/vegetable/mineral

My work has always been a blending of organic forms, with the intention of creating wearable objects that seem both familiar and uncanny. I've looked to both the zoological and botanical world for structures, systems, and patterns that I can repurpose and filter through abstraction. More recently I've been playing with implausibility, looking for colors and patterns that would help further eschew recognizability, and reveling in strangeness. At the same time, I've also been ruminating much more on transgression and how the natural world can sometimes defy easy reduction and categorization. There is a direct link in my productivity and risk taking in the studio to my rage, heightened anxiety, and rebellion against the rise of bigotry in the US. Coupled with the desire to amplify the ambiguity, peculiarity, and otherworldly qualities in my work, references to non-biological forms have become very interesting to me, and I find myself now exploring alien territory. This current body of work that is becoming animal/vegetable/mineral is much more overtly about defiance, and in particular, taking the form of objects that are exhuberantly, confrontationally weird.
story_txt:
Iowa to Munich

I'm a full time artist based in Iowa City, IA.
I've spent the last couple of years evolving toward new work loosely under the banner of "animal/vegetable/mineral"
Munich Jewellery Week is the largest international venue for contemporary jewelry.
Getting to share this new work with the international community at MJW is very exciting!
The shop I will be exhibiting in, Louloute, will offer a unique setting to create an installation for this work.

I'm Broke, but I Can't Miss This Opportunity

Lodging at Pension Belo Sono for $378.98 for March 11-18. This location is ideal not just because of the price, but because it is on Gollierstraße, right across from Louloute!
There is a rental fee for the venue  of about 350€ (excl. VAT) which will be between $450 and $500 (US) depending upon where exchange rates are by the time I get there.
The travel costs to Munich are about $1100, with the potential for luggage fees given all that I need to bring with me.
I would like to live on more than peanut butter for the week if possible.
Having done a fundraiser before, I've learned that it isn't so smart to make the perks overlap with the work of the project. This time I'm fully embracing the potential of swag, and with the help of Ben Smasher, we will be producing a variety of merchandise with peculiar images generated from this work.
These funds will go toward keeping me from digging myself even deeper in credit card debt!

The Impact
Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know the difference their contribution will make:

I know my work isn't exactly everyone's cup of tea, but I am always happy to find the folks it really resonates with. 
Being based in Iowa City, many people only experience my work in the form of digital images. However, when I get the opportunity to share them in person, I think it is so much more resonant.
This is the third time I've turned to crowdfunding to complete a project, having used it once before to get to SIERAAD with Ben as my assistant, and before that to bring a group of 10 US jewelry makers to SIERAAD as well. 
Surviving as a full time artist is filled with risk. The support and encouragement I've gotten over the years is invaluable. This next opportunity feels especially exciting given both the platform, and where I am at in my practice.


Why Do I (And All Artists) Need Financial Support?
It is not easy surviving as a full time artist. Very few make it a full time profession, and most of those are often subsidized from personal wealth. Americans are acclimated to both painfully low wages and cheap consumer goods, so we have limited options for a collecting public. Additionally, other arts funding is more scarce, and directed at work that has the least chance of commercial viability. Essentially, making weird objects that are both functional and labeled "jewelry", but which are challenging in many ways, makes life hard for all of us art jewelry makers.
I've spent the last seven years trying different fairs in different locations hoping to hone in on who, exactly, my work is most appealing to. Last year, bolstered by the volume of work I've been producing, I tried to juggle multiple fairs on a schedule that I know many other artists manage well, or even exceed. Though I met many amazing people, and I'm glad I got to share the work in person as it always makes for a deeper connection, the end result left me in rough shape. Overall, I'm always the weird kid at fairs, and it is a very draining experience. I pushed myself too hard trying to off-set the expenses, juggled workshops to subsidize, did a very bad job at taking care of myself, and still ended up in the red and worse for wear physically. I want to make this exhibition work, but I don't want to spend the rest of 2019 wondering how to survive because of it. Any help with this is deeply appreciated!

Other Ways You Can Help
I know a lot of you reading this are artists/makers as I am. I wouldn't have made it this far without the support of other artists. However, I know that means many of you are in the same place I am: trying to sustain a creative life on slim margins. If you can't support me right now, I understand. There have been times when I had extra money to help a friend's project, and there have been times when I had nothing to spare. Just help me share this, get the word out, and if you're coming to Munich in March, please come by and say hello!
/
More Info About My Work/This Series
Polyphonous: animal/vegetable/mineralMy work has always been a blending of organic forms, with the intention of creating wearable objects that seem both familiar and uncanny. I've looked to both the zoological and botanical world for structures, systems, and patterns that I can repurpose and filter through abstraction. More recently I've been playing with implausibility, looking for colors and patterns that would help further eschew recognizability, and reveling in strangeness. At the same time, I've also been ruminating much more on transgression and how the natural world can sometimes defy easy reduction and categorization. There is a direct link in my productivity and risk taking in the studio to my rage, heightened anxiety, and rebellion against the rise of bigotry in the US. Coupled with the desire to amplify the ambiguity, peculiarity, and otherworldly qualities in my work, references to non-biological forms have become very interesting to me, and I find myself now exploring alien territory. This current body of work that is becoming animal/vegetable/mineral is much more overtly about defiance, and in particular, taking the form of objects that are exhuberantly, confrontationally weird.

story:
Dear Community and Friends,

Please consider supporting us producing large scale Human Aerial Art and turn them into Dance prayers for Unity and Fraternity.

It's been amazing to receive all the community support. It took us to South Africa where we just produced the face of Mandala with 1200 people in the Karoo desert It was phenomenal collective prayer; deeply healing and unifying. Soon, we'll release the picture into the media, sending a second wave of inspiration around the world.

This part was phase 1 of the mission. We're now calling forth for your support to get us to Rio for the Earth Summit and Portugal for more Dancing for Change and Aerial Art.

Everything Help and make a big difference. Consider joining us.

Our Intention

  • Inspire visually and viscerally a thriving and sustainable future worldwide by reaching hundreds of thousand of people through social and traditional media.
  • Activate hundreds of thousands of people across generations and cultures to take creative actions to build a thriving and sustainable future.

The Plan

The adventure will start on April 23 in the desert of South Africa and then continue in Rio during the Earth Summit in June and culminate at the largest transformative dance festival in Europe, Boom Festival.

AFRIKABURN, South Africa (April 23 to May 10).
In the desert near Cape Town, we'll be creating a human aerial art and ecstatic dance prayer with 1000-2000 people to convey the message of Ubuntu* at the Afrika Burn.
 
* Ubunto is an African philosophy of life advocating mutual caring for each other and for the whole.


RIO+ 20 (Earth Summit 2012), Brazil  (June 9-23)
We'll be going to Brazil for Rio + 20; the most important gathering of Heads of States, NGOs and business leaders focused on Sustainable Development. Our work will focus on supporting Amazon Watch's campaign to save the rainforest - and more specifically stopping the Belo Monte Dam from being built. 


BOOM FESTIVAL, Portugal (July 20-August 7)
We'll be heading to Portugal to lead transformative ecstatic dance journeys for healing and liberation and to give a talk about the Power of Art in Activism. This will take place at the largest dance festival in Europe: Boom Festival.

 

The Impact

  • Inspire people to take creative conscious actions for a thriving and sustainable future.
  • Provide main stream and social media with a creative outlet that will awaken the heart of their audience and generate important conversations on issues of our time - including stopping the construction of dams in the Amazon Rainforest. Our network of NGO partners will help us dissiminate the messages and embodied experience we create.


What we need

Good news: most of our on-site travel and production expenses are covered by partner organizations. All we need is to raise the funds to get Magalie on site and cover minimal additional costs: 

  • Flight* to South Africa: $1500
  • Flight to Rio & Amazon:$1850
  • Flight and transportation to Boom location, Portugal: $1620
  • Documentation (editing & materials): $1000 
  • Contingency for food, lodging and misc.: $1000
  • Indiegogo + fiscal sponsor fees (10%): $680 

* all flights depart from San Francisco, CA.

If you would like to donate airmiles to cover one of those flights, please email Magalie directly at m@dancingwithoutborders.org. That would be deeply appreciated.

 

What's in it for you

We'll take you on this journey with us, keeping you updated through the travel blog, videos and images. We'll be sharing with you the craziness, the challenges and especially, the power of gathering thousands of people together to dance for collective transformation.
 

The Team

Dancing without Borders' upcoming productions will be orchestrated in partnership with internationally recognized artist John Quigley of Spectral Q.

 

About Magalie Bonneau-Marcil

Magalie Bonneau-Marcil, the founder of Dancing without Borders, is a dance facilitator and producer of interactive art for social change through mixed media. She is dedicated to weaving diverse communities together to heal, liberate ourselves and co-create a new positive narrative for humanity through dance and human aerial art photography. In 2011, she produced and directed the viral One People flash mob in partnership with CODEPINK and N.O.W. Within a month, it reached 150,000+ people on YouTube. She also produced the short Embody the movement video to capture the power of Art in Activism as part of the Occupy Movement.

 

About John Quigley

John Quigley, the Founder of Spectral Q, is an internationally known Artist and Producer. His unique mix of human installation and aerial photography brings together communities to create large-scale messages for the common good.

He has created more than 150 Aerial Art images involving over 150,000 people on 7 continents. Locations have ranged from the Amazon Rainforest, Antarctica, London, Geneva, Athens, Delhi, Johannesburg, Copenhagen, Bonn, Toronto, Mexico City, Australia, Java, Bali, Chile, Belize, Peru, Brazil, Alaska, Vancouver, the Arctic, Los Angeles, cities across the United States, and the United Nations in New York. In 2008 he began the Icon Series with aerial portraits of Nelson Mandela (as part of the 90th Birthday celebrations in South Africa) and Martin Luther King Jr. on behalf of Amnesty International and The Elders.

His body of work has been profiled in the London Sunday Times Magazine and has appeared in hundreds of media outlets around the world including Time Magazine, The New York Times, Washington Post, Los Angeles Times, Miami Herald, International Herald Tribune, Le Monde, Stern, CNN, BBC, NBC, CBS, ABC, Discovery Channel, Entertainment Tonight, In Touch Magazine as well as award-winning books and documentaries.

 

Thank YOU for helping us make all of this possible!

story:
Hot Glass Sculpting

Yogesh, a young artist from the small Indian Village has a rare gift. He is one of those few artists who can transform a piece of glass into anything he wish – birds, fishes, animals, fruits, trees and even humans hunting in the wild. Anything and everything that he can imagine can be sculpted from the molten glass.

And he does it without electricity, moulds, dies or any special equipment whatsoever. Just a kerosene burner flame, glass rod, broken pieces of colored glass bangles and ordinary home tools.

Even the compressor required to regulate the flame intensity is pedal operated and designed and custom built entirely from cardboard. Isn't that amazing?



The process, known as Hot Glass Sculpting, is deceptively simple.The glass crystals are softened into viscous fluid by directly inserting in the flame and then given the desired shape and colors before it cools down. That is it....no rocket science.

But as said, the simplicity is misleading. Transforming the glass crystals into a colorful sculpture with perfect details and proportion, needs fluid harmony between imagining and executing.

Eyes, fingers, wrist, feet, brain... in fact every part of the body needs to align itself and co-ordinate with others to bring the sculpture into existence. It’s nothing short of a meditation and there is no margin for error.

And yet despite all its novelty, hot glass sculpting is a dying art.

There were times in history when India had Kings with a keen eye for arts that are beautiful, unique and mesmerizing. They encouraged artists to explore the unimaginable by rewarding them handsomely, not just with gold but also with public recognition. And so, the culture of experimentation in arts flourished. Stone, clay, glass, wood, paper, metal everything and anything would be worked upon and turned into something magnificent.

But slowly, with the advent of industrialization and mass production, the traditional arts began to be neglected and in search of daily livelihood the artists ceased to transfer their skills to the next generation.

Amongst such arts that are on the verge of extinction is Hot Glass Sculpting and Yogesh is amongst a few artists who are keeping it alive even today.

Yogesh’s family has been making hot glass sculptures for centuries with the skill been passed on from one generation to other. But both Yogesh and his elder brother, were reluctant to pursue the life of an artist, for they've seen it brings neither money nor recognition. It’s a life of struggle that nobody would choose to live.

But then destiny has its own way…and when his Father, who had been making sculptures for 30 years, suffered from a stroke, Yogesh had no choice but to fall in and soon discover that the skill came naturally to him. He has been creating and relishing these beautiful sculptures for past 12 years now.

Living in a rented small village home, Yogesh has simple dreams…first to start his own academy wherein he can pass on the art to as many as possible and second to someday live in his own home.

You can help Yogesh to fulfill his dreams. Please check our perks and contribute if you feel it is worth. Your support will empower Yogesh to continue making this world more beautiful.

 

The Perks

$1: Thank You!



A very heartfelt thanks for supporting this cause…We will send you a digital collage of the step by step process through which a hot glass sculpture is made.


$15: Artify your home

Any sculpture of your choice from the list that we will share with you before confirming the shipment.

Before shipping, you'll be asked for the sculpture of your choice.

Add $6 for shipping.

$33: A special Christmas gift for your special someone

Encased in a specially designed glass enclosure with a mirror backing for enhanced visual effects and comfortably sized at 2.5” x 2.5” x 1“, this is an ideal Christmas gift for your dear ones. You can customize this by choosing any animal, bird or a fish of your choice along with a plant/tree in the background.

Add $9 towards shipping.


$51: A memorable Gift for your best friend or dearest sibling

A pair of sculptures representing you and your best buddy along with a plant/tree encased in a specially designed glass enclosure with a mirror backing for enhanced visual effects and sized 4.5” x 2.5” x 1“ makes this a gift that anyone would cherish.

Add $9 towards shipping.


$99: Artify your office desk

Bring freshness and creativity to your office space with this specially designed 6” x 4” x 1.5” desk art and cherish the joy of seeing your visitors awestruck by the sheer beauty of it. 

Free Shipping.



+ Video of the sculpture being made

+ Printed Collage of the complete hot glass sculpting process for you to share the story

+ Free Shipping


$123: A family’s tale

A snapshot of a life in the forest, this fabulous piece showcases a family, a herd, a group of animals or birds wandering in search of food and making us realize of our own luck and responsibility.

You can customize by choosing the animals you wish to possess in this beautiful 5" x 11" x 2"  glass encased artwork. 

Free Shipping.



+ $33 perk

+ Video Cd 

+ Printed Collage

+ Free Shipping


$189: Customize a forest story in your home

             


Every kid (including the one in an adult’s heart) loves to make his/her own jungle and play with it. Well, we will be glad to help build your own jungle, customize it at your will and create settings that can relate to different stories and basically have plenty of fun.

Choose any 10 sculptures and we will complement it with 5 more, all packed in an exclusive hand crafted, organically colored Bamboo Box worth $30.



15 sculptures of your choice (each worth $15)

+ $30 worth hand crafted, organically colored bamboo box

+ $51 perk, gift packed for your loved one

+ DVD 

+ Printed Collage

+ Free Shipping


$333: Seize the hunt: Limited Edition Exclusive

Seamlessly communicating action, emotions & adventure, this ultimate piece of sculpting would inspire your young ones to get creative and weave a story around it, even as your guests are awestruck at its magnificent details.

The limited edition portrays a scene from a popular Indian Epic “Ramayana”, wherein the two brothers Ram & Lakshman are seen chasing deer, while on a 14 years exile in forest.




+ $99 perk gift packed for your loved one

+ DVD 

+ Printed Collage

+ Free Shipping


$666: Collector’s Edition - Autographed  (Save $384)

If collecting exclusive arts is your hobby, then this perk is something you should not miss.

A complete collection personally signed by the artist, packed in an exclusive hand crafted, organically colored Bamboo Gift Box worth $120 makes this a perfect fit into any personal gallery while also saving you a whopping $384. 

                            


The collection contains

15 solo sculptures + 5 Sets (one of every size, as seen above) 

+ $120 worth hand crafted Bamboo Gift box

+ DVD 

+ Printed Collage 


$1599: Create your own hot glass sculpture with the artist and explore the world famous caves of Ajanta and Ellora

An exclusive opportunity to meet the artist in person, get to know the first hand history of this rare art, get a hands on training and maybe create your very own hot glass sculpture in the process.

And of course as an art enthusiast, we know you’ll be delighted to witness and personally explore the historically beautiful, world famous caves of Ajanta and Ellora. Just pack your bags and fly to us, we’ll take care of your stay, food and a 2 day tour.

Also, while you are here as our guest, we’ll be delighted to gift you a complete collection of all sizes from the above perks personally signed by the artist


The Impact

The Background Story

How would the world be if there were no artists?

This question has been hitting me every time I came across an artist who is struggling to survive in this modern digital world, and by luck I've met many in last 4 years. 

Gifted with a rare skill and imagination, this artists find hard to fit in the changing times. One one hand the society is neglecting them and on the other machines and industries are competing with them to win that coveted place on the wall or in the display shelf.

Their misery can be summarised by what a painter had to say when I questioned about such low prices for her exquisite art, 

"People don't buy art these days, they buy the raw materials (colors & canvas) and are only willing to pay us the surcharge as labor for putting them in certain pattern. Imagination, vision, skill these are not tangible..what value could they have?"

And yet, she painted. She painted not for her buyers but for herself, for her satisfaction. After all, being an artist has its own curse, they'd rather die than do something that is not creative!

Yes, there are artists who gained name, fame, money everything the world could offer...but then these are very few. 

There are tens of thousands more, each with a unique gift, struggling to carry on with their life just because they have no means or knowledge to display their passion, their life to the global audience.

And that's where Empowering Arts was born. We aim to showcase the passion and skills of such grass root artists to the world community and in turn empower and honor these artists with a place that they deserve. 

This is our first effort and the money raised will help us to strengthen the platform by turning Yogesh's dreams into reality.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute at this time with a pledge, but are enthusiastic about the project, your enthusiasm is contagious! Please spread the word through Facebook, Twitter, or blogging and you can use the share tools or links at the bottom of this page. 

Good old word of mouth is great too! 

We are truly grateful for your support.

maybe create your very own hot glass sculpture in the process. 
And of course as an art enthusiast, we know you’ll be
delighted to witness and personally explore the historically beautiful, world
famous caves of Ajanta and Ellora. Just pack your bags and fly to us, we’ll
take care of your stay, food and a 2 day tour. 
Also, while you are here as our guest, we’ll be delighted to gift you a complete collection of all sizes from the above perks personally signed by the artist



The Impact

The Background Story
How would the world be if there were no artists?
This question has been hitting me every time I came across an artist who is struggling to survive in this modern digital world, and by luck I've met many in last 4 years. 
Gifted with a rare skill and imagination, this artists find hard to fit in the changing times. One one hand the society is neglecting them and on the other machines and industries are competing with them to win that coveted place on the wall or in the display shelf.
Their misery can be summarised by what a painter had to say when I questioned about such low prices for her exquisite art, 
"People don't buy art these days, they buy the raw materials (colors & canvas) and are only willing to pay us the surcharge as labor for putting them in certain pattern. Imagination, vision, skill these are not tangible..what value could they have?"
And yet, she painted. She painted not for her buyers but for herself, for her satisfaction. After all, being an artist has its own curse, they'd rather die than do something that is not creative!
Yes, there are artists who gained name, fame, money everything the world could offer...but then these are very few. 
There are tens of thousands more, each with a unique gift, struggling to carry on with their life just because they have no means or knowledge to display their passion, their life to the global audience.
And that's where Empowering Arts was born. We aim to showcase the passion and skills of such grass root artists to the world community and in turn empower and honor these artists with a place that they deserve. 
This is our first effort and the money raised will help us to strengthen the platform by turning Yogesh's dreams into reality.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to contribute at this time with a pledge, but are enthusiastic about the project, your enthusiasm is contagious! Please spread the word through Facebook, Twitter, or blogging and you can use the share tools or links at the bottom of this page. Good old word of mouth is great too! 
We are truly grateful for your support.

story:
Indian Intergenerational Theatre Company

"Intergenerational Theatre - A celebration of life with the goal of bringing joy, laughter, and playfulness to every community in the Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry community."  

My name is Gus and I have been working in Tamil Nadu & Pondicherry, India for the past two years helping several communities come together to develop India's first Intergenerational Theatre Company.  The company will be made up of seniors from Tamaraikulam Elders Village and students from the Cuddalore Isha Foundation School. Both of these communities rose from the Tsunami relief effort post-2006.

HelpAge India will act as the organizational home for the theatre company and they have already recruited two highly qualified graduates from Pondicherry University - Dr. Bala Pazani & Ms. Sugantha Lakshmi - to be directors of the company and the Pondicherry University’s Dean of Performing Arts - Dr. Gunasekaran - to be Creative & Cultural Consultant for the company. This company will begin rehearsing in October culminating in their first performance scheduled for November 27, 2014.

In the first two weeks of October, a group of students from Victoria, Canada and I will be training the directors of the company in Intergenerational Theatre techniques as they have been used in Canada and United States most notably by the GeriActors and Friends in Edmonton, AB and Roots and Branches in New York. After this period, the Indian directors will take what they learned from the Canadian theatre artists and adapt the model to be culturally appropriate for India.  

What We Need Help With

We need funding to help with:

  • Supplying the company with materials for costumes, masks, and make-up for their first performance and tour. 
  • Paying the directors for their first two months of work.

Between myself and HelpAge India employees, we have organized several performances that will fund the company into the future. We only need help with the first two months, once we have this start-up funding the company will be able to fundraise their own money.

The Impact

Often Elders and Students in rural areas of India do not have their views represented in their communities. This theatre company will offer a platform for Elders and Young People to join together in solidarity to express themselves. By donating to this company you will be:

  • Giving a platform for people from marginalized communities to have meaningful communication with the Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry community
  • Contributing to the well-being of the Elders – extensive research has found links between healthy aging and involvement in the arts
  • Providing children with a chance to learn from their elders – many of the elders in this project were alive when famed Indian leaders like Sri Aurobindo, Gandhi, and Nehru were alive and they remember when India first gained independence in 1948 – these seniors are living history and the youth have the chance to re-live it through the stories of their elders
  • Backing a project that has a proven track record – both GeriActors & Friends and Root & Branches have sustainable histories of positively impacting their communities – I have a personal history of being involved in Intergenerational Theatre Companies since 2006 and I have seen a wonderful sharing take place that enriches the lives of every individual involved

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot give financially to our current fundraising campaign you can still help by:

  • Spreading the work about our campaign to as many people as possible (share this on Facebook or Twitter and email anyone you think might give)
  • Taking the time to share joy, laughter, and playfulness with an elder in your community or if you are an elder do the same with us young folks (sometimes we need to be forced away from our phones but trust me you make our days when you share your lust for life)

Thank you for taking the time to read this. Please remember to share joy, laughter, and playfulness intergenerationally whenever possible.

Sincerely,

Matthew “Gus” Gusul

story:
Hi everyone,

First of all, let us introduce ourselves! We are three graduate students, two from China: Uta and Xinyue and one from Mexico: Sofia, and together, we are co-curating I Dreamed I Was Asleep, the first solo show for Iranian contemporary artist Habib Saher.

About the Exhibition

I Dreamed I Was Asleep, is a new series of paintings and sculptures that deal with the artist’s conflicting relationship with mortality and the concept of the afterlife.  

Through these works, we are confronted with Saher’s intimate relationship and doubts about the religious belief on life after death and human interaction and the influence his culture’s religious and political beliefs has had on this ongoing questioning.

As part of this project, the artist has chosen to showcase the works in a specific atmosphere, a completely dark room. Each piece has its own lighting mechanism, and the contrasting light creates a dramatic, nightmare-like ambiance. It is through this sensorial and intellectual stimulation of moving within the shadow-filled, dark space that the viewer not only experiences the artworks, but is immersed into the artist’s conception of the afterlife; a dream of being asleep.

About the Artist

Habib Saher (born 1986, lives and works in Iran, Azerbaijan and Paris) works with a wide variety of materials and his investigation revolves around the thematic of death and temporality. He has both a BA and MA in Sculpture from the Baku State Art University in Azerbaijan. He’s had both group and solo exhibitions in Iran (Naghsh Gallery), Azerbaijan (Artim Art Space, Yarat Contemporary Art Space, H.Aliyev Center, Baki Gallery, Baku Academy of Arts), and in the United States (Seed Corn Gallery, California). He is now showing for the first time in Paris. 

I Dreamed I Was Asleep will take place at:

IESA la galerie, 1 Cité Griset 75011 Paris, France

November 22- 27, 2017

Opening: Wednesday November 22 from 7-10 PM

What We Need & What You Get

Since we are students, you might understand we are dealing with very limited budgets, and this is why we are asking for your help!

Your contributions will be directed towards:

-Shipping and Packaging Costs

-Mounting material costs

-Publicity costs (Printing costs for flyers and posters, fcbk post boost, etc)

-Opening night logistics costs (Refreshments, printing of mediation material)

Depending on the level of your contribution, apart from a huge thank you from our team, you'll also receive a small token of appreciation. 

What for?

The goal of this project is to introduce Habib Saher into the French art scene and help him further his career.So, if you are passionate about art and are interested in this artist and his work, help us make this exhibition happen!

story:
I am Sophie Swoffer, an associate artist of De Montfort University. I am also a recent MA graduate from DMU after completing my postgraduate degree in Performance Practices there.

This campaign/event is an opportunity for artists/students from across the Midlands to come together and share their skills and knowledge from their artistic areas in order to learn off one another and create together through improvised play. The individuals involved will be engaging in an evening of improvised activities with which are focused on building relationships and trust. We aim to bring together dancers, musicians, performance artists, photographers and many more uniting their unique talents and creating something spectacular as a result!

This campaign is extremely important to me as I am aware that are not many opportunities available at the moment specifically in the Midlands that enable artists of different disciplines to collaborate, as a consequence artists often shy away from working with other artists that do not share their particular skill sets. From personal experience, I have found that when I have collaborated with students from different artistic backgrounds we have learnt a great deal from one another which has in turn benefited our own practice and given us more confidence as practitioners.


Ideally we would need £800 of funding in order for the event to take place. This would cover:

1) Paying staff that we have employed to help aid the event such as, security and helpers to dress and clean the space (insisted by the venue at £20 an hour), extra helpers to help transport equipment and set up equipment, photographers and film editors to record the event.

2) Purchase of the refreshments, food and alcoholic beverages.

3) Surface materials to keep the space safe and comfortable. We aim to create a 'chilled area' within the space where artists can get to know one another and discuss their subject areas in a relaxed areas so we would like to purchase some materials and throws to create this section, along with seating such as bean bags or sofas.  We also want to use plastic sheeting to protect walls in the space where artists such as painters or performance artists could get their creative juices flowing and have the freedom to use paint and other materials without harming the space.

4) Room hire

The event will be held in Two Queens Leicester http://2queens.com/, which is the perfect location for the event with its massive and industrial space. 

"Two Queens is an artist led studio and gallery complex situated in Leicester’s Cultural Quarter. With the ambition of providing a centre for experimental modes of arts production, exhibition and exchange, Two Queens is dedicated to establishing an agenda for new activity in the city and across the region." --Two Queens

5) Public evnet liability 

There will be 3 main insurances that we need to cover for the event:  Employers Liability, Public Liability and All Risks (Equipment).

6) Pre-Show Promotion

Myself and my colleague (also an associate artist of DMU and co creator of the event) will be performing a pre-show to the event at DMU to entice people to come to the event where we will be engaging in improvised activities. Here we will be giving out tickets to our audience which will provide them with one free drink when coming to the event to hopefully increase the number people who come to the event and to create some excitement for it.


This project is extremely valuable in establishing a strong community relationship between artists in the midlands and across the country, bringing together their unique talents and skills. Collaboration between artistic individuals is something that we see as essential in sustaining performance art as a culture. Uniting artists that would not normally work together has the potential to create amazing partnerships that would not of otherwise been found. Improvisation is a fantastic skill to have in performance, as it shakes individuals lose of their inhibitions and worries and instead enables them to trust their instincts and welcome the unknown in order to make fantastic discoveries along the way. Combining improvisation with the mish mash of artistic disciplines holds fantastic potential!
Our aim is to get rid of the stigma of dancers just working with dancers and musicians with musicians and instead enable individuals to embrace the unknown and build trust within artistic communities leaving the opportunity for future collaborations.
This is the first project that myself and my colleague have engaged in without institutional guidance but is a path that each of us are extremely passionate about and would love to be able to continue to do in the future. Your help would be extremely important and vital in us learning more about the help that is available and we would love to offer our help in return, whether it me further advertisement of indiegogo or getting more people involved in your projects.
Obviously there are many potential problems and obstacles in place against us achieving our goal. Firstly as aforementioned my colleague and myself are new to this and so may be unfortunately overlooked as a consequence. However we are both completely invested in this event and are perpetually seeking advice from experienced individuals and drawing on our contacts from the local performance community.
Also as the event is centred upon improvisation there is of course potential for many problems as we cannot predict what the performers may do or whether they will successfully collaborate with one another. However we are undertaking research in how to avoid this and are embracing the unknown as something beautiful but risk filled. We have also recruited a 'host' figure to help the events along on the evening to try to help motivate situations who has a catalogue of experience in improvised activities. My colleague and myself are also training in how to lead warm up exercises that relax and motivate the participants.
Also we are going to have musicians which will play throughout the evening so the atmosphere and mood of the session never fully drops and there is always the potential for something exciting to happen.

Thank you so much for reading this pledge and we would be so appreciative if you could share and pass on the event to people you think may be interested, the more the merrier!

story:
Space & Time Collective is a creative team exploring politics and feminism in fan culture.

Writer Caitlynn Fairbarns and illustrator Sophie Paas-Lang work together to create beautiful fan works exploring their favourite aspects of geek culture. Their small press debut, May the Force Be With Her, is an illustrated history of the women in the Star Wars franchise.

After several months of hard work and planning, we are ready to share our zine, May The Force Be With Her, and we want to throw a party! We have had so much fun working on this project and want to share our excitement and joy with everyone, with food, drinks, a panel discussion and great music! We want people to come together to have a fun and enlightening conversation about female representation in Star Wars and more broadly in geek/sci-fi culture. 

In order to have this celebration, we are looking for some support from our family, friends and loved ones. We hope to raise $600 to help cover the costs of the location, food, beverages and other additional costs. Any additional funds we receive will go directly to jumpstarting our next exciting project together!

story:
Our Story

The SANATA International Hair Braiding and Natural Hair Care Magazine. This is a 9 1/4 X 12 1/4 size Magazine that showcases the creativity and skills of hair braiders and natural hair professionals in the United States. The Magazine is published yearly and we are currently working on producing the 5th Edition which will mark the 5th Anniversary of the publication. Unique Magazine that bridges the braiding and natural hair care communities with a full fledged 120 pages of artistic braids and natural hair designs. The Magazine is published by ebraiding.net.


The Impact

The Magazine is currently the unique bridge for the braiding and natural hair care communities and showcases creative work and artistic designs of our members.


What We Need & What You Get

1. Paperback Cover copy of Magazine for each backer who pledges at least $25
2. Two VIP Tickets to attend the Annual Premiere event for each backer who pledges $100 or more in addition to 1
3. Each backer who pledge $500 or more in addition to 1, and 2, will have her or his name listed in the Fifth Edition of the Magazine


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help spread the word about the campaign

story:
K9 Mark IV-BM

Help us build K9 of Dr Who fame as an art car. K9 will provide space for a driver and approximately 4 passengers. The driver sits on K9's back and the passengers will stand on the side of K9 with their feet on his lower running boards. With his passengers, K9 will traverse the far reaches of the universe and see that they return home safely.

K9 dimensions will be approximately:

  • Length - 8' 10" (269 cm)
  • Width - 5' 4" (152 cm)
  • Height (at head) - 7' 5" (213 cm)
  • Height (at back) - 5' 6" (152 cm)

K9's first public sighting will be at Burning Man 2014 with the primary mission to be ambassador to the people of Burning Man for the Quixote's Cabaret Club & Bar camp. The QCCB cabaret venue will be decorated in the style of the Tardis from Dr Who and at various times, the camp members will be costumed as characters from the show or characters they imagine would be in the Dr Who universe. By traveling the pathways of the playa, K9 will be able to let people know about the camp and cabaret that will be held on various nights.

Who We Are

Peter has a professional background as a software developer but has been working as a senior studio manager and pyrotechnician at The Crucible in Oakland for the past 8 years. He bring strong design and fabrication skills in metal working, foundry work and fire. He'll be tapping into his extended community of friends in the San Francisco Bay Area to help bring K9 to life. The work will be done at Peter's studio at Lost & Foundry Oakland. 

Mary brings a strong editorial bias and outstanding project management skills. Her ability to wrangling artists is legendary and will help keep the project on target and on time.

Treee, a QCCB camp member since 2006, is also a researcher  in the Centre for HCI Design at City University London and a lifelong maker/tinkerer. She will be crossing the Atlantic several weeks before the Burn to apprentice herself to Peter and make sure that anyone who drives or rides K9 has the best possible user experience.

Olivier has been wrangling with computers and robots since he was a small child. He still has nightmares from his first viewing in 1975 of Dr Who and hopes that building K9 will have a therapeutic effect. He’s wanted an Art Car since his first burn in 2006.

Monty has been part of Quixote’s cabaret since 2005, when he was one of team who should have known better and decided to run a Cabaret camp at BRC from the UK! He has always been far too interested in science fiction and the adventures ofa certain Doctor. Basically, as we are building the TARDIS on the playa this year, our first Art Car had to be either a sofa (to hide behind) or K9!

QCCB & K9

Here's some members of the Quixote's Cabaret Club & Bar on the project:


What We Need & What You Get

With the funding that you help provide, we will:

  • Repurpose an electric golf cart to be the base frame.
  • Upgrade the suspension to better support the new load and passengers.
  • Build an internal frame of aluminum and add a aluminum skin.
  • Fabricate the support and mechanism needed to move the steering controls to the head of K9.
  • Create the mechanisms needed for K9's head and antenna to move.
  • Add a CO2 nozzle and laser to K9's nose.
  • Set up a sound system to play K9 sounds.
  • Add lights for night driving.

In turn, we'll give you:

  • Our thanks.
  • Stickers, patches and t-shirts with the K9 Mark IV-BM project logo.
  • Your name immortalized on K9's back panel.
  • Art tours on the Playa.
  • Ice deliveries to your camp on the Playa.
  • An opportunity to drive K9.
  • A visit from K9 to a place of your choosing in the San Francisco Bay Area.

Stretch Goals

  • For an additional $2,250, we can upgrade the base cart to be a utility vehicle instead of a golf cart.
  • For $500 over that, we'll upgrade the frame and skin to stainless steel.
  • And for an additional $500, we'll add a large scale flame effect to K9.

Other Ways You Can Help

We realize that some people can't contribute directly to the fund but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Tell your friends and family about the campaign and ask them to support it. 
  • Share the campaign on Twitter, Facebook and your favorite social site.
  • If you're in the San Francisco Bay Area, volunteer some time to help build K9.

Watch the progress of creating K9 on the build blog at http://k9markivbm.com.
story_txt:
K9 Mark IV-BM
Help us build K9 of Dr Who fame as an art car. K9 will provide space for a driver and approximately 4 passengers. The driver sits on K9's back and the passengers will stand on the side of K9 with their feet on his lower running boards. With his passengers, K9 will traverse the far reaches of the universe and see that they return home safely.K9 dimensions will be approximately:
Length - 8' 10" (269 cm)
Width - 5' 4" (152 cm)
Height (at head) - 7' 5" (213 cm)

Height (at back) - 5' 6" (152 cm)

K9's first public sighting will be at Burning Man 2014 with the primary mission to be ambassador to the people of Burning Man for the Quixote's Cabaret Club & Bar camp. The QCCB cabaret venue will be decorated in the style of the Tardis from Dr Who and at various times, the camp members will be costumed as characters from the show or characters they imagine would be in the Dr Who universe. By traveling the pathways of the playa, K9 will be able to let people know about the camp and cabaret that will be held on various nights.Who We ArePeter has a professional background as a software developer but has been working as a senior studio manager and pyrotechnician at The Crucible in Oakland for the past 8 years. He bring strong design and fabrication skills in metal working, foundry work and fire. He'll be tapping into his extended community of friends in the San Francisco Bay Area to help bring K9 to life. The work will be done at Peter's studio at Lost & Foundry Oakland. Mary brings a strong editorial bias and outstanding project management skills. Her ability to wrangling artists is legendary and will help keep the project on target and on time.Treee, a QCCB camp member since 2006, is also a researcher  in the Centre for HCI Design at City University London and a lifelong maker/tinkerer. She will be crossing the Atlantic several weeks before the Burn to apprentice herself to Peter and make sure that anyone who drives or rides K9 has the best possible user experience.Olivier has been wrangling with computers and robots since he was a small child. He still has nightmares from his first viewing in 1975 of Dr Who and hopes that building K9 will have a therapeutic effect. He’s wanted an Art Car since his first burn in 2006.Monty has been part of Quixote’s cabaret since 2005, when he was one of team who should have known better and decided to run a Cabaret camp at BRC from the UK! He has always been far too interested in science fiction and the adventures ofa certain Doctor. Create the mechanisms needed for K9's head and antenna to move.
Add a CO2 nozzle and laser to K9's nose.
Set up a sound system to play K9 sounds.
Add lights for night driving.

Our thanks.
Stickers, patches and t-shirts with the K9 Mark IV-BM project logo.
Your name immortalized on K9's back panel.
Art tours on the Playa.
Ice deliveries to your camp on the Playa.
An opportunity to drive K9.
A visit from K9 to a place of your choosing in the San Francisco Bay Area.
Stretch Goals
For an additional $2,250, we can upgrade the base cart to be a utility vehicle instead of a golf cart.
For $500 over that, we'll upgrade the frame and skin to stainless steel.
And for an additional $500, we'll add a large scale flame effect to K9.
Other Ways You Can HelpWe realize that some people can't contribute directly to the fund but that doesn't mean they can't help:
Tell your friends and family about the campaign and ask them to support it. 

Share the campaign on Twitter, Facebook and your favorite social site.

If you're in the San Francisco Bay Area, volunteer some time to help build K9.
Watch the progress of creating K9 on the build blog at http://k9markivbm.com.

story:
Berlin, ville de tous les possibles, berceau des nouvelles formes d'art, j'arrive!

Grâce à vos appuis sincères, je pourrai réaliser mon rêve de me perfectionner à Berlin avec les plus grands de la jonglerie de balle contact, en plus de partager ses bienfaits méditatifs avec le public de la rue.
Cet élan n'est pas né d'hier...

Dès l’âge de sept ans, alors que j’enfilais pour la première fois des chaussons de ballet, je sentis l’appel vers un dévouement total envers les arts de la scène et l’expression corporelle. Un de mes rêves d’enfance était aussi d’être une acrobate nomade dans un cirque ambulant. Plusieurs années plus tard, j’ai poursuivi des études aux ateliers de danse contemporaine de Montréal et au School of Toronto Dance Theatre, en plus de développer des aptitudes dans diverses acrobaties et de m’investir dans une pratique soutenue de yoga ashtanga. Puis, en 2012, ma rencontre avec l’artiste de rue Jonathan Ortegua fût des plus significatives. Grâce à ses enseignements, j’ai pu développer une pratique alliant danse contemporaine et balle contact, qui s’emboîtent et se canalisent, à laquelle j'ai ajouté récemment la manipulation d'un ballon suisse. Ce concept innovant me transporte et je souhaite le faire voyager en même temps que j'offre un moment d'enchantement aux passant des rues du monde. Que le calme méditatif de la balle contact entre en fusion avec l’énergie et la puissance de la danse, dans un style mystérieux et fantomatique, laissons-nous envelopper par le charme de la balle contact! 


Soutenir un rêve de toujours qui prend forme aujourd'hui

Votre soutien financier me permettra défrayer les coûts des ateliers offerts par le centre Katakomben, où je prendrai des classes de maîtres, en plus de m'y entraîner intensément. De plus, il pourra me donner un coup de pouce pour les frais de transport et d'hébergement. Merci de votre soutien!

Vos contreparties

J'apprécie - 5$ ou 10$

J'apprécie votre soutien. Vous serez inscrit(e) à mon infolettre!


Merci! - 25$ et plus

Je vous remercie! Vous serez inscrit(e) à mon infolettre et vous recevrez des remerciements publics sur ma page Facebook Isabulle.


Wow, merci! -50$ et plus

Je vous remercie avec un wow. Vous serez inscrit(e) à mon infolettre et vous recevrez des remerciements publics sur ma page Facebook Isabulle et vous recevrez une balle souvenir autographiée ou une carte postale de ma part si vous habitez dans la région de Montréal.


Wouhou , merci!- 100$ et plus

Votre soutien est inestimable, merci! Vous serez inscrit(e) à mon infolettre et vous recevrez des remerciements publics sur ma page Facebook Isabulle et vous recevrez une balle souvenir autographiée et une carte postale de ma part si vous habitez dans la région de Montréal. 


Êtes-vous tombés sur la tête, triple-wow, merci! -250$ et plus

Je veux tellement vous remercier que je ne trouve plus les mots. C'est pourquoi j'irai performer 15 minutes de balle contact dans un de vos partys ou fête de famille pour vous exprimer ma gratitude, d'ici à mon départ pour Berlin. Vous serez aussi inscrit(e) à mon infolettre et vous recevrez des remerciements publics sur ma page Facebook Isabulle et vous recevrez une balle souvenir autographiée et une carte postale de ma part si vous habitez dans la région de Montréal. 


Mille fois merci et soyez bien à l'aise de partager cette page à tous les gens que vous connaissez qui ont à coeur la démocratisation de l'art et les moments de magie!

story:
Greetings! this is Helen.


Most of you visiting this campaign or supporting it will already know me and my work, but for those who don't or only know a little bit here is me:

I am an Australian artist currently based in Melbourne. I am self taught and have been working full time in the arts for most of my adult life.

My 35th birthday is this month (June). (it was cool - I had a pirate party)

My life has held many challenges which I am constantly working to improve and grow through. Art has been a great tool for me throughout my life.

I'm holding this campaign to raise some capital I can use to prepare for my solo art show that I have coming up. All the set up costs such as framing will be supported by the funds raised here.

Now I'd like to give you a fuller picture of where I'm coming from so you understand why I'm asking for help now.. here are a few brief points:

-I have recently (late last year) separated from a 10 year relationship and business (arts) partnership, and am still trying to find my feet again in the new world without him. I have chosen to hold this art show to embrace and announce myself as an artist in my own right stepping back into the scene. Kinda a 'getting back on the horse' moment for me. 

-Also in the past 6 months while I was going through the separation I also finally realized I was unable to continue working with one of the loves of my life: oil paints. I have developed a dangerous sensitivity to the paints after using them for 20 years or so. My health has really suffered. So now I'm not only stepping up to the mark and 'relaunching' my career as a solo artist, but I've had to reinvent so much about it, right down to the medium and technique I use, and doing under the extra pressure of rather poor health. (I'm loving my new work though! and hope you do too!)

-If that wasn't enough.. also in Feb 2014 my Father was granted parole and released from prison in QLD, which has triggered and stirred a lot of my Post Traumatic Stress disorder symptoms - because he was serving an 11 year sentence for abusing me as a child.


It doesn't rain - it pours! I've had a lot on  my plate as you can see, but my goal now is to create beautiful things that bring joy into the world. That's my life's mission I think. Turning crap in to gold - in 'life alchemy'.  I'm doing everything I can to make positive progress to step up and to be proud, to face the challenges and make a difference in the world. I am a strong person - I'll tell you though asking for help has not been a strong point of mine.. just a little bit of support from you lovely people here will make SO much difference to me. It will give me that solid ground to build build build my dreams from. Thank-you so much!


Funds info:

the funds raised will be used on:

- printing, promo and framing costs for my solo art show 'Dreams of the Fae' to be held though-out July 2014 at 'The Sooki Lounge' in Belgrave (vic)

If I reach my target - please keep supporting me above that amount. Extra funding I raise here I will use to do things like pay for a live band to play at the opening night on July 2nd (so there is no cover charge needed on the night) and extra on top of that I will use to cover costs associated with bringing my art back to full power. Art supplies, promo, websites, insurance etc..

My goal is $1111 because I like 11s :) people who know me will know that. I've estimated I need to raise around about $1000 to cover the urgent costs - but $3000 would cover lots of extra's I can kinda do without if needed. the $111 is to cover the indigogo fees and because it makes a nice 'round number' to me.

About the Perks:


  • The perks on offer are mainly my new work that will be for sale at the show - with some discounted prices on some here. It's kinda like for people who can't get to the shows, that they get to be a part anyway, as well as people can get in early and support it in advance. I'm really excited by my new ink work and hope you will be too. 
  • the print range is available to view in the gallery section of  this campaign.

The Impact:

I'm too stubborn to give up on my goals to do beautiful art and improve my quality of life, but with your help it will be so much easier and less stressful.. I will be able to put my energy into the things I do well - the artwork!
I'd also like to note that I want to be achieving as much as I can in my life. As a support and living example for other people who are survivors of childhood (or any kind) of abuse. I have already started speaking to the media about my story in support of other victims. I will attach links to here too if you are interested in hearing/reading my interviews on this subject.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not in a position to contribute financially to the campaign (or even if you do) but would like to help more you can also help out by:

  • You can try to get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Indiegogo  has some awesome share tools!

I'm sorry I just used a picture not a film to explain all this.. I currently have limited resources for such things like making films - but you all know me anyway :)

thanks for stopping by and supporting me <3

Many enthusiastic hugs,

Helen
