story:
About Force Field Project

Force Field Project uses innovative art and creativity to call attention to the potential of neglected spaces in economically struggling neighborhoods in Philadelphia. We bring large-scale, interdisciplinary art installations that explore a variety of mediums including performance, video, sound, and sculpture.

On June 21-22, 2014, Force Field will showcase 45 installations, performances and musicians representing 7 states including Pennsylvania, Delaware, New York, New Jersey, West Virginia, Massachusetts and Maryland.

Force Field is a project of CultureTrust Greater Philadelphia, a charitable trust supporting diverse cultural practices in the Philadelphia region.

Event Details

Dates and Times:

Saturday, June 21st, noon-2am

Sunday, June 22nd, noon-6pm

Location: 

3525 I Street & 3401 I Street, Philadelphia, PA 19134

See where they are on Google Maps.

What We Need

  • 60% of funds goes directly to the artists to make their work.

  • 20% of funds supports the musicians playing at the event.

  • 20% of funds helps pay support staff, print our program guide,  and rent port-o-potty's.

The Artists

45+ artists from 7 different states.

See images of everyone's work on our website.

Tiernan Alexander. Jaime Alvarez, Annmarie Avila, Joe Bartram, Timothy Belknap, Create in Situ, Julia Bunn, Jessica Clark and Veronica Cianfrano (CHER), Lewis Colburn, Christina P. Day, Tim Eads, Jes Gamble, Sean Gerstley, Chris Golas, Tyler Henry and Alex Burkat, Maddie Hewitt, Maiza Hixson and Lauren Ruth, Matt Kalasky, Mike Treffehn and Lori Miles, Eun Hye Kang, Tyler Kline, Patrick Koziol, Ron Lambert, Anthony Marasco and Joe Patitucci, Derek Glenn Martin and Louise O’Rourke, Ezra Masch, Taryn McMahon and Keith Lemley, Alex Nguyen and Mark Dilks, Sui Park, Yangbin Park, Joanna Platt, Kyle Psulkowski, Adams Puryear, Emily Puthoff and Elena Sniezek, Casey Ramirez, Mike Richison, Tangle Movement Arts, Raul Romero, Hiro Sakaguchi, Black Shesus, Ben Sloat, Sister Spaceship, Charity Thackston, Zach Trow, Anne Vieux, Hannah Wnorowski, Misha Wyllie

King Britt will be performing Saturday night.

Tangle Movement Arts will be performing Saturday during the day.

Perks

**If you are interested in contributing to our project, but will not be able to attend we will gladly donate your ticket to a youth organization in the neighborhood we are working in. 

Why support our event?

+ The space for this event totals over 200,000 square feet and will showcase artists from many different mediums.

+ Force Field promises to attract 1,000+ people. (based on Data Garden’s 2012 event, The Switched-On Garden 002).

+ While the audience is all ages, the event appeals most heavily to the 21-40 year old demographic who are interested in art exhibitions, experimental art installations, attending cultural events, communities repurposing abandoned  buildings, and community revitalization.

+ A secondary audience for this event is area youth ages 14-21 who are interested in arts and culture initiatives, careers in the arts, and have an interest in community revitalization.

+ Food and drink from local food trucks and breweries will add to the ambiance of the 2-day festival.

+ Force Field will partner with area youth serving organizations to provide free festival tickets for youth and guided tours during installation and the event, providing youth an opportunity to see first-hand how a festival of this magnitude is coordinated and engage with artists whose work interests them.

The opportunity

Kensington is one of the most racially and ethnically diverse regions of the City, boasting a large population of Latino Americans (mainly Puerto Ricans and Dominicans), African Americans, and Irish, Italian, and Polish Americans. Each of these distinct groups brings a wealth of cultural traditions to their community that contributes to its vibrancy.

Kensington is also home to a thriving arts and culture scene with many neighborhood nonprofits and local artists

contributing to the revitalization of the neighborhood. Philadelphia at large is flooded with artists, musicians, and performers that need support to complete and exhibit their work.

Decades ago, Kensington had a thriving textiles industry. Today, Kensington’s unemployment rate is nearly 30% and the media has stigmatized it as the “Badlands” due to higher rates of poverty, food insecurity, and drug related crime than any other Philadelphia neighborhood.

With the support of local businesses and organizations Kensington has the potentional to evolve into a beautiful neighborhood.

Force Field is a project of CultureTrust Greater Philadelphia, a charitable trust supporting diverse cultural practices in the Philadelphia region.


Our Sponsors

If you would like to sponsor our event please contact us.

The Artists45+ artists from 7 different states.See images of everyone's work on our website.Tiernan Alexander. Jaime Alvarez, Annmarie Avila, Joe Bartram, Timothy Belknap, Create in Situ, Julia Bunn, Jessica Clark and Veronica Cianfrano (CHER), Lewis Colburn, Christina P. Day, Tim Eads, Jes Gamble, Sean Gerstley, Chris Golas, Tyler Henry and Alex Burkat, Maddie Hewitt, Maiza Hixson and Lauren Ruth, Matt Kalasky, Mike Treffehn and Lori Miles, Eun Hye Kang, Tyler Kline, Patrick Koziol, Ron Lambert, Anthony Marasco and Joe Patitucci, Derek Glenn Martin and Louise O’Rourke, Ezra Masch, Taryn McMahon and Keith Lemley, Alex Nguyen and Mark Dilks, Sui Park, Yangbin Park, Joanna Platt, Kyle Psulkowski, Adams Puryear, Emily Puthoff and Elena Sniezek, Casey Ramirez, Mike Richison, Tangle Movement Arts, Raul Romero, Hiro Sakaguchi, Black Shesus, Ben Sloat, Sister Spaceship, Charity Thackston, Zach Trow, Anne Vieux, Hannah Wnorowski, Misha WyllieKing Britt will be performing Saturday night.Tangle Movement Arts will be performing Saturday during the day.Perks**If you are interested in contributing to our project, but will not be able to attend we will gladly donate your ticket to a youth organization in the neighborhood we are working in. Why support our event?+ The space for this event totals over 200,000 square feet and will showcase artists from many different mediums. + Force Field promises to attract 1,000+ people. (based on Data Garden’s 2012 event, The Switched-On Garden 002).+ While the audience is all ages, the event appeals most heavily to the 21-40 year old demographic who are interested in art exhibitions, experimental art installations, attending cultural events, communities repurposing abandoned  buildings, and community revitalization.+ A secondary audience for this event is area youth ages 14-21 who are interested in arts and culture initiatives, careers in the arts, and have an interest in community revitalization. + Food and drink from local food trucks and breweries will add to the ambiance of the 2-day festival.+ Force Field will partner with area youth serving organizations to provide free festival tickets for youth and guided tours during installation and the event, providing youth an opportunity to see first-hand how a festival of this magnitude is coordinated and engage with artists whose work interests them.The opportunityKensington is one of the most racially and ethnically diverse regions of the City, boasting a large population of Latino Americans (mainly Puerto Ricans and Dominicans), African Americans, and Irish, Italian, and Polish Americans. Each of these distinct groups brings a wealth of cultural traditions to their community that contributes to its vibrancy. Kensington is also home to a thriving arts and culture scene with many neighborhood nonprofits and local artistscontributing to the revitalization of the neighborhood. Philadelphia at large is flooded with artists, musicians, and performers that need support to complete and exhibit their work.Decades ago, Kensington had a thriving textiles industry. Today, Kensington’s unemployment rate is nearly 30% and the media has stigmatized it as the “Badlands” due to higher rates of poverty, food insecurity, and drug related crime than any other Philadelphia neighborhood. With the support of local businesses and organizations Kensington has the potentional to evolve into a beautiful neighborhood.Force Field is a project of CultureTrust Greater Philadelphia, a charitable trust supporting diverse cultural practices in the Philadelphia region.Our SponsorsIf you would like to sponsor our event please contact us.

story:
Emerging Artists Need Your Help!

Across the River Arts needs your help to showcase the work of 22 talented emerging visual and performing artists at the Fremont Abbey Arts Center on July 12, 2012!  The theme of the work will reflect the selected artist’s interpretations of “Extraordinary in the Everyday.”  This event is an opportunity for developing artists to showcase their work to a welcoming audience and reach an innovative section of the arts community.  Be one of the first people to support these artists on their path to creating groundbreaking work.

Show Details                                                    

Visual artists will be featured in a gallery/café space in the Abbey from 7:00-11:00 pm, and selected art will remain in the café until July 26th. The performance will be from 8:00-10:30 pm with an extended intermission to view and talk with the visual and performing artists. 

Show artists were selected through an open call process in early May and will include a variety of disciplines including painting, photography, mixed media, sculpture, video/film, dance, music, spoken word, and theater.  The show will represent a collection of work from many disciplines, allowing a well-rounded experience for artists and the audience alike. Visual artists may choose to sell work at the show as well.  See a similar show we hosted in 2011, Twentyfive http://www.acrosstheriverarts.org/our-projects/. 

Show Expenses

This event is produced entirely by volunteers, including artistic director Ginny Sanchez Ballard and collaborator Jeff Ballard. We have worked to make the show as inexpensive as possible and are lucky to have the sponsorship of the Fremont Abbey Arts Center to help with space costs, insurance, equipment, and much more.  Abbey volunteers are helping by accepting in-kind services for running sound and day-of show coordination.  We will have a volunteer photographer and poster designer as well.  Income from ticket sales goes directly to the artists if we reach our goal.

Your donation will help pay for:

  • Space Rental & Gallery Supplies: The Fremont Abbey Arts Center covers some of these costs, but your donation helps cover the costs for gallery supplies, a house manager, café staff, sound and lighting equipment and other rental fees and gallery supplies.
  • Videographer: We believe it is vital for the performing artists in the program to have documentation of their work. We will also be able to use this documentation to advocate for funding in the future.
  • Print Materials: Artist call poster, show posters and cards, event programs – we make sure to get non-profit rate to help keep our costs down!

Sponsor

This show is sponsored in part by The Fremont Abbey Arts Center, a vibrant community venue for people of all ages and incomes to be supported in their artistic & social development through new collaborative arts & cultural experiences.  The Abbey focuses on music, dance, visual, literary and culinary arts in formats including multi-arts performances, group classes & workshops, individual lessons, new exhibits and artistic life celebrations.  It is a non-religious non-profit organization.

More information:

http://www.acrosstheriverarts.org/current-shows/

http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/252854

https://www.facebook.com/events/426165314070381/

Thanks for taking the time to read about our project!  Your support means so much to our community-based arts group and the emerging artists who will have the opportunity to show work, sometimes for the very first time in Seattle!

story:
THE PLUME PROJECT IS A SPECTACLE UNLIKE ANY OTHER      

Using poetry, education, power, and light this project will impact the residents, workers, and visitors of downtown St. Paul. 

The Plume Project will use the steam plume from District Energy's Biomass Power Plant as a high profile stage for light displays, addressing the topic of energy within three distinct artworks. 

Emily Stover will use poetry to talk about city infrastructure 

Aaron Dysart is representing NASA Satellite data of the sun’s surface

Asia Ward is creating a community drawing platform about positive energy 

This three month event in the sky will crown the city during the coldest months in Minnesota when the plume often stretches across St. Paul like a massive cloud.  With theatrical flood lights and a large venue projector the Plume Project will celebrate an internationally recognized community energy system and also bring attention to St. Paul’s newly minted Eco District.

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

This project is too big to be carried by a handful of people.  We know its impact will be huge.  We simply cannot do it alone.  This is a fantastic project and it needs your help.  

We have secured a matching grant through the Knight Foundation so every dollar you donate will be matched.  Our goal is to have you back us in any way you can, so that during the coming winter you can look above the city of St. Paul and know you played a part in something big. 

You can help us create a powerful stage for artists and an environmental education platform in the sky.   Thank you for your support. LET'S LIGHT THE PLUME!  

WHERE YOUR MONEY GOES

Your tax-deductible support will light the plume throughout the winter of 2015-2016 by allowing us to hire professional technicians, obtain equipment suited for this highly exposed location, and mount the first-rate city-scale public art installation Saint Paul deserves. Please consider being a part of making the Plume Project a beloved part of Saint Paul this winter. 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

Anything you can give to support this project matters to us, and will help make the project a success.  If you can't contribute with a donation, that's okay!  There are other ways you can help: 

  • Help us get the word out about the Plume Project.  Pass on our campaign by sharing it, telling people about it, liking us on Facebook, and tweeting about us, 
  • If our campaign is funded, keep an eye out for a call for artwork, and submit!
  • Volunteer opportunities will become available. Sign up and we'll keep you updated. 
  • Come and check out the projects during their show times! Document and share!

THE STORY

For years, the artists of the Plume Project have worked and lived in downtown Saint Paul, fascinated and wonder-struck at the majestic cloud coming from the District Energy St. Paul facility. Upon taking a tour we learned the power plant generates local energy primarily from renewable and efficient energy sources and is recognized as a world-class facility. Inspired by the tour, we wanted to know if the steam plume could be used as a canvas for large scale projected displays.  So we got together around a campfire and simulated the steam plume with a stockpot of water.  As soon as we flipped on the video projector the vapor came to life.  It was magical to look at!  

THE ARTISTS AND THEIR PROJECTS

VOICES FROM THE DEEP     NOVEMBER 2015

EMILY STOVER is a multidisciplinary designer and public artist whose work focuses on temporary environments, experiential art, and public engagement as ways of investigating how people live together within the landscape.

Voices from the Deep, will commission local poets to create original work about District Energy and its presence in the city. Utilizing a theatrical light show that is triggered by a phone system, the public will call a number to hear one of the poems read for them alone, while the plume’s lights are animated in sync for the entire city to see.


SOLAR SYSTEM    DECEMBER 2015/JANUARY 2016

AARON DYSART is a sculptor whose environmental interventions push ideas of propriety, gift giving, and reciprocity. He has exhibited nationally, and has received support through numerous local foundations and organizations.

Solar System will use data from NASA’s Solar Dynamic Observatory to present an ever-changing light show on the plume. As spots and storms ebb and flow on the sun (the “power plant” at the center of our solar system), color-changing flood lights inside the steam plume will shift and dim in tandem. The dynamic nature of our ultimate source of energy will be made visible throughout downtown Saint Paul.

PLUME COLORING CONTEST    JANUARY/FEBRUARY 2016

ASIA WARD works between the realms of science, art, and education. Through her work with the Science Museum of Minnesota, REcharge Labs, and for artist residencies around the US, Asia creates public art projects and educational activities about the environment, water systems, and electric power production.

Plume Coloring Contest is an open call for local residents to submit content based on the topic “Positive Energy.” Selected images will be curated and projected onto the District Energy steam plume for the whole city to enjoy.


MAJOR SPONSORSHIP LEVEL PERK INFORMATION

Banner: A 6’ x 20’ banner will be installed on the western wall of downtown District Energy plant at Kellogg Boulevard and Market Street from October 2015 through February 2016.  This highly visible location, adjacent to the Science Museum and the George Latimer Library, will ensure prime exposure to Kellogg Boulevard pedestrians and vehicle traffic.  Additional street signage is planned for the duration of each project. 

Launch Party: 11-17-2015  5:30pm-7:30pm. Be among the first to see the plume illuminated! All sponsorship levels include tickets to our Light The Plume event in November 2015, including a lighting ceremony.  This party will take place inside a warm and cozy room at the Science Museum of Minnesota, with the best view of Plume Project in the city. 

Media Exposure: Sponsoring the Plume Project at a Partner level will attach your company’s name to relevant press releases and social media outreach, as well as on the website and process blog.  Based on current levels of interest, this project is expected to get extensive coverage in local media as well as reach a national audience. 

Plant Tour: See where the positive energy happens! Partner-level sponsors will gain behind-the-scenes access to the District Energy plant, along with artist and staff that have made the project possible. 

CREDITS

Video/Animation by Asia Ward 

Music by Joe Grigar

Photos by Aaron Dysart, Asia Ward, Emily Stover, Andrea Steudel

story:
Short Summary

We (Alicia Milne and Luis Vasquez La Roche) are both visual artists that have been working collectively on urban projects under the alias ‘Pinky & Emigrante’ since 2011.

 

 

‘Pinky & Emigrante’ have been selected to represent Alice Yard art space during our stay at the Stichting Open Ateliers Zuidoost (OAZO AIR) artist in residence program from July 1st – August 30th 2013 and we are excited!

OAZO AIR is a not for profit organization that manages sixty artists’ studios in Amsterdam Zuidoost. Through the Amsterdam Fund for the Arts, OAZO AIR has turned two of those spaces into a work studio and a living studio available for visiting international artists. OAZO AIR funds the living space and work studio but the selected artists are responsible for their own travel, living and material costs. 

Amsterdam Zuidoost is a large culturally diverse city with many immigrants and a large active arts community. OAZO AIR expects selected artists to interact with the local community and create projects relevant to the space. We find Amsterdam Zuidoost to be a very exciting location for our first artist residency as we both make artwork relative to the cultural complexity found in Trinidad and wish to investigate any parallels between the societies of Amsterdam and Trinidad. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Our total budget for international and domestic travel, living expenses and material expenses for the two of us for the two-month stay is US$11,800. The Ministry of Arts and Multicultralism has already supported by contributing US$5,900 to our cause.

We would love your help in raising US$4,000 for the residency expenses. We estimate we can handle raising the rest of the budget on our own. 

Your contributions will help us get to Amsterdam safely and explore the city, and most importantly allow us to develop our collaborative and personal projects while we are there! 

Have no fear, even if we do not reach the full target for this campaign we will still be participating in the residency - if necessary we will just adjust the length of our stay or the materials we use.

We have some attractive incentives for supporting. We have created a series of signed 4x6 inch lino prints specifically for this campaign. Below you can see the 8 prints available to claim as a perk when you support.  

Pinky's perks

 Emigrante's Perks

 

The Impact

This residency will give us the time and space to pursue projects that may not be possible in our everyday circumstances. It will also offer exposure to new ideas and collaborators, a chance for us to expand our contacts internationally, and gain valuable knowledge of other creative contexts.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute to our cause financially that's ok! You can support us in other ways - please spread the word about our campaign to your friends. The Indiegogo sharing tools make it easy to spread the news over social media.

Thank you for your support and words of encouragement so far.

Lots of love from P&E,

Alicia and Luis

story:
come help me build a 'CROWD' box!

i need collaborators for my Nuit Blanche Ottawa 2013 'crowd box' project. it only works if you connect with me and here is one way how...

would you like to connect with other humans? does anonymity make it easier? i invite you to touch me. human connection at its most basic.Or make a basic human connection in the "crowd" by reaching out on twitter @heARTbeatgalART #NBO13crowdbox  i will not be able to see you but I trust in the power of positive human inter-action. 

imagine...over the night of NBO13, september 21st, 2013, i want to connect with as many people in the crowd as i can, in the name of creative humanity.

there is to be an actual box.  that i am to build. (with some talented help!)

the night of, i will be inside the box on the patio at Social restaurant in the byward market, not able to see out through the see-through mirror plastic walls. holes will be cut for collaborators to reach in and touch me. if not. tweet me. 

the kicker is the special (as in, especially expensive) see-through mirror plastic that i need to purchase to create the right environment for the concept. it is essential that collaborators in the NBO13 crowd be able to see me, touch me, without my seeing them. anonymity is key so that interaction is encouraged. 

the project is fundamentally based in crowd participation, thus, i am reaching out to the crowd for funding as well. it is very tricky to place financial value on art, let alone, conceptual art pieces like this one. i drew up a budget. i am looking only to recover costs.

why do this?

mostly because i am compelled as an artist obsessed with human connection and collaboration; it is an evolution of my collaborative work; and, 'the crowd' is where my art lives. www.theheARTbeat.ca

the crowd is big, diverse and has something to contribute! maybe in some way here!

funds. touch. tweets. let's connect! help me see this (crazy) dream through!

xxo

heARTbeatgal

story:
When You Dream Big You Build Community

At the Imagination Installations Project, a 501(c)(3), we believe in co-creating our world by unleashing the power of imagination one dream at a time.

Through this campaign we want to shine the spotlight on the powerful, positive people in our community who are taking action to make their world a better place.  By donating even $1 YOU become one of those people.

Two Ways Your Donation Will Make a Difference

1)  Imagine driving down business 40 and seeing billboards that inspire you or make you smile instead of just seeing ads for people trying to sell you stuff. 

2)  Imagine that our community is rich with positive, interactive public art that helps people of all ages access their dreams for the future and what they want to create for themselves, their children, their pets and the earth. 

When you donate to this Dream Campaign you will be using your imagination to co-create the world you want to live in.

1) Imagine When… Billboards

Last year The Imagination Installation (ii) Project ran beautiful and evocative digital billboards on Business 40 and Hwy 52 featuring dreams from real people in Winston-Salem.  

All the dreams started with the statement "Imagine When...."

People told us how much they loved seeing the billboards when they were driving on the highway because each time they read one they got a mood-boost or felt inspired to dream bigger in their own life... or for our community.

We need your help to bring the Imagine When.... Billboards back.

Think about how cool would it be to see YOUR dream on a Billboard. Dreams we showcased on Business 40 included:

Imagine When... We greet strangers as friends. ~ Cheryl

Imagine When... Compassion guides our decisions. ~ Jerry

Imagine When...  Healthy food is available to everyone. ~ Deb

Imagine When... All animals are treated with respect. - Sandy

Imagine When... Every child can read. ~ Annie

Imagine When... We educate vs. incarcerate. ~ Shelley

2) More Interactive Public Art!!!

We also want to generate more interactive public art in our community.

Local artist Wren Wilson, as part of Imagination Installations, has been invited by Associated Artists to create a fabulous new interactive exhibit for the lobby of the Milton Rhodes Arts Center. But her invitation didn't come with cash.... so we need some to pay for her supplies and creativity.

Wren has designed a large scale, interactive exhibit that features 3-D, 8-foot high reflective shapes that will be suspended from the ceiling. As the shapes gently turn, our community’s dreams will be showcased and people will see their image in the mirrored surfaces. Wren hopes people will be inspired by the installation to understand that they are also dreamers and are the ones responsible for creating the life they want.

Below is a photo of Wren at the New Winston Museum. She is standing in front of the public art installation she created for Imagination Installations with the help of youth from Authoring Action. The project was part of Winston-Salem's Centennial Celebration.

What We Need & What You Get

Our project budget is $3,133.  The funds we raise will go to:

$460 for materials to create the interactive public art exhibit including: giant foam core, reflective sheets to cover the foam core, paint and other secret supplies Wren uses to create.

$400 to local artist Wren Wilson for a very small portion of her time concepting, researching, designing and building the art installation with the knowledge she gained, in part, during her time at Salem College.  We have a big dream that all artists get paid for their community work. By donated to this campaign you can be part of making that dream come true.

$2,273 for six weeks of space on prominent digital billboards on Business 40 to showcase dreams in our community from people like YOU.

What Will Happen If We Raise Extra Money

We can have space on multiple billboards throughout the Triad for a few months… or heck if this this goes viral and people are uber generous… for a year!  

Wren can make our next public art exhibit even more intricate and expansive and could even do a second installation using the dreams people shared in this first piece.

Risks & Challenges

This is a BIG dream that comes with challenges.  If we don't meet our goal:

- We will only be able to have your dreams featured on a billboard for a few days vs. a few months.

-  Wren's art installation will have to be scaled down dramatically and won't have the large scale WOW factor she envisions.

But we are confident that that won't happen.  Why? Because since Imagination Installations launched three years ago we have seen the generous, amazing people in our community step up to the plate to help dreams come true.  Now YOU have a chance to be part of the Tribe of Dreamers that loves making big things happen.

Why is Dreaming and Imagination Important?

We believe that everyone is using their imagination all the time to co-create our world. We are aware of the nightmares some of us have inadvertently dreamed into being. We created this Project to model positive dreaming and the use of imagination so that people can consciously create communities that are connected, compassionate, healthy, abundant, creative and vibrant.  For the past three years we have also witnessed something amazing that happens when people learn how to dream in the positive and share their dreams out loud. They discover that other people share their dream... or become inspired to take action to help them build their dream. The cross-polinization of imagination and connections have immediate impact.

Who is ii?

Imagination Installations (ii) is a grassroots project, newly incorporated as a 501(c)(3), fueled by artists, entrepreneurs, community leaders, teachers, business owners, shamans, executives, poets and others who love to innovate and dream big in their own lives and for their communities. We launched on a beautiful fall day at Camino Bakery in Winston-Salem, NC in 2011. The next year we expanded into Greensboro when one of our founding volunteers, Cyndi Briggs, delivered a TEDx Talk on the power of Imagination.

The Imagination Installation Project is about the art of "Dreaming Into Being." We love building Imaginariums and dream-incubators with the Triad Tribe of North Carolina. Imaginariums are places (i.e. our web site, public art installations, events) where people can record their dreams and discover what others have shared using the statement "Imagine When..."

Imagination Installations' Board of Directors/Vision Circle:

Teddy Burriss, Sheri Clawson, Taylor Johnson, Tim Johnson, Cheryl Schirillo-Johnson, Sandy Phocas, Subash Shah, Robin White Star, and Amanda Zabel.

To see a long list of other people who have been part of the ii Project since 2011 visit our web site: ImaginationInstallations.com

Other Ways You Can Help

Look to top right of this page for the fun donation perks.

There are also other ways you can contribute to making our community vibrant by supporting this dream-based, imagination project:

- Email the link to our Indiegogo Page to friends, family and co-workers.

- Share on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn and other social media platforms.

- Dream Big in your own life and inspire others.

Thank you so much!

story:
About Us

Fierce Fest is a radical queer and feminist arts festival taking place in Bellingham, WA October 3rd-5th, 2014.  We created Fierce Fest to provide more support and visibility for queer, female, and trans artists in our community.  We are dedicated to dismantling oppression, creating safe spaces, building community, and empowering marginalized voices.
Our goal is to present you with 3 days of music, films, visual art, performance art, poetry, workshops, skill sharing, karaoke, fashion, and dance parties!  We plan to do this all in all-ages accessible spaces.


Our Fundraising Goals

Fierce Fest is completely volunteer run.
Our goal is to raise $800 which will go towards:
  • Renting accessible venues.
  • Reimbursing artists, bands, and workshop facilitators for their time and travel expenses.
  • Printing zines and promotional materials.
Any remaining funds will go to support Queer Rock Camp in Olympia, WA and Girls Rock Camp in Bellingham, WA.


Our Manifesto

FIERCE FEST is a radical queer & feminist D.I.Y. festival dedicated to dismantling oppression, building community and empowering marginalized voices.
Because we can use art and music as tools for empowerment, reclaiming space, solidarity and education.
Because we refuse to accept unsafe, oppressive conditions for marginalized people in our communities and the under-representation of trans, queer and female artists.
Let’s build intentional, accessible, all-ages safer spaces in which consent, call-outs and accountability are encouraged, as well as continuous learning and growth.
Our ambition is fierce when it comes to standing up for marginalized people and inspiring our community. Let’s be loud, take back space, take care of each other and TAKE ACTION!
Bellingham, WA, October 3rd-5th 2014. We acknowledge that this event is taking place on colonized Lummi and Coast Salish territory.


Get Involved

We are always looking for artists and volunteers!
Find us on the web:
http://fiercefest.tumblr.com
http://facebook.com/bhamfiercefest
Or contact us at:
fiercefestbellingham@gmail.com

story:
The Conference of the Birds 

A sumptuous multi-sensory dance theatre presentation 

by EnActe Arts and Sangam Arts

Written by Peter Brook & Jean Claude Carrière 

Based on 12th Century Persian Poet Farid ud-Din Attar's Manṭiq-uṭ-Ṭayr 

THIRTY dancers and FIFTEEN actors representing TWELVE ethnic traditions spanning FOUR continents feature in ONE vibrant, multi-sensory interpretation of the timeless Sufi quest narrative - The Conference of the Birds.

All donations to this unique cause are tax-deductible!

Why are we doing this?

The story: 

The Cast: This spellbinding allegory of the philosophy of Sufism will be rendered by actors and dancers representing 12 ethnic traditions.  Fifteen experienced actors and thirty dancers form the cast. 


Parrots & Herons - Folklorico dancers (Los Lupenos de San Jose) will play the role of Herons & Bharatnatyam dancers (Navia Dance Academy), the parrots!

Partridges, Exotic Bird, Ducks - Belly Dancers (Hala Dance), Aztec  (Yoli Parra) and Hula (Halau Napuaokamokihana‘ohaikapolioluana)  dancers play the roles of partridges, exotic bird and ducks!

Sparrow, Dove, Phoenix, Peacocks - Played by Chinese peacock and ribbon dancers (Haiyan Dance Company) and Modern Ballet (sjDanceCo) 

Kathak (Antara Asthaayi), Afro-Brazilian dancers (World Fusion Dance) perform myriad roles.

The Team

The Advisors


EnActe Arts is a fast growing,  ground breaking theatre company on the Pan-American scene, acting as a window into South Asia and a platform for talent development in the performing arts.

Sangam Arts is curator and presenter of the finest collaborative works between world class dance communities. 

Every dollar you donate will go towards fees for the performing artists. Your donation will help open the doors to this and future multicultural collaborations. Several grant organizations, corporations and individuals have already rallied behind the project to cover other production costs.

story:
Fallen Stars - D.O.D.

                 D.O.D. - "Dangers of Drugs"

The introduction picture of me holding the painting of Gabby Douglas represents the heights that can be reached by our youth when they are not influenced by the dangers of drugs. There are a lot of Gabby Douglas's in the world; some will and some will not achieve the heights that this young star has risen to be. With this campaign hopefully it will influence other youths to follow the example she has set and not let the D.O.D. extinguish their glow.

I Linwood Pettaway have been an artist all of my life, drawing pictures since the age of twelve. I have always been interested in drawing portraits. Besides doing portraitures of family members; I have enjoyed doing the faces that we all love and recognize. Residing in Hollywood for over 10 years led me to become even more interested in the drawing of famous people.

It is sad but true that some of the biggest names in entertainment have "Fallen" due to the use of Drugs; both legal and illegal.

I believe that by bringing to the publics attention in the form of a well illustrated portrait series of some of the most highly recognized "Fallen Stars"; that it will help raise the awareness in our youth and society as to the real "Dangers of Drugs". Upon finalizing this series’ editions; they will be displayed in public places where our youth gathers; IE: homes, schools, universities, libraries, galleries, and businesses across the US to further increase their awareness as to the dangers of drugs. This will help start the discussion of this public dilemma and how each of these well known figures lives had been ended by the D.O.D. "Danger of Drugs". The length of time that one engaged in its’ use placed a long toll on themselves, their loved ones & relatives; and should have been avoided. With this campaign this awareness will hit home.

I am asking for your support & funding in order that I may apply the "time" necessary to complete this "Fallen Stars - D.O.D." series. We are seeking to raise $25K to help cover some of the funds that will be needed to sustain the expenses of our Art Gallery and Studio space during this time. Funds will be used to purchase the materials & supplies required to Print & distribute the pieces that you will receive as gifts for your pledges. Funds will also be used to produce multiple copies of this series in order to get them out to the public to have them displayed in the venues mentioned above.

Each of these (27) "Fallen Stars" will be rendered in Colored Pencil. The reproductions will be limited and hand signed personally for each pledge; matted and/or framed based upon your level of pledge. For those of you who are more generous in your pledging; you will receive Originals as well as Framed and Matted Prints.

If our funding goal is not fully reached in the allotted time period; we will use the funds we have at that time to produce as many sets possible. Our main goal is to get this "Fallen Stars – D.O.D." series in as many schools, universities and public libraries as soon as possible.

If you are not able to help with funding at this time; please help us by getting the word out to parents, business owners, local & state government figures and school administrators. By getting others to follow our project; it will increase the awareness of our "Fallen Stars" series that we will soon have available. These tools will help start the open discussion of what really does happen to one when they are involved with drugs; legal or illegal. The real images that hit home are of the ones we have in our memories of a close friend or relative whose lights were never allowed to shine. With your help we can maintain the needed momentum to get this series out to the public ASAP. Please use the Indiegogo share tools to help us reach a larger audience.

 

Thank you for your time, efforts & pledges. Help us successfully reach our goal; which is to get this D.O.D. discussion started with

the completion & conveyance of this portrait series. Let’s make this happen!

Remember my Indiegogo link to share is:         {  igg.me/at/Linwood-Artist  }

You may also go to my Profile link
directly with:     { indiegogo.com/Linwood-Pettaway }

 

 

Thank you,

Linwood Pettaway,  Artist & Illustrator

 

* Included with each Fallen Star will be a Bio of how each one of their lives

      were taken by the use of drugs - D.O.D. "Dangers of Drugs".


* All Reproductions are signed & matted.

 

* Shipping & Handling: 

Please add equivalently the below American currency as to the number of Framed

pieces and Matted pieces that will be mailed and/or shipped. Also include the

full address of where they will be mailed or shipped to.

 

* Within the U.S.:

For each matted piece include $2.00 each

For each framed piece include $10.00 each

NOTE: If you have a mix of (2) framed & (2) matted include $20.00

(Matted pieces will be included in same shipping box)

 

* To Canada & Int’l:

For each matted piece include $6.00 each

For each framed piece include $15.00 each

If you have a mix of (2) framed & (2) matted include $30.00

(Matted pieces will be included in same shipping box)

 

* Pledges & Perks:

Perks are alphabetized & the Fallen Stars are numbered.

 

*Note:

The availability list of the Originals will be kept up in Gallery / 4 

Please check that list before requesting your preferred choice(s).

 

(27) Fallen Stars - D.O.D.

 1. Michael Jackson

 2. Thomas Kincaid

 3. Len Bias

 4. Rick James

 5. Janis Joplin

 6. Jim Morrison

 7. River Phoenix

 8. Jimi Hendrix

 9. Cory Monteith

10. Lenny Bruce

11. Anna Nicole Smith

12. Kurt Cobain

13. Judy Garland

14. John Belushi

15. Amy Winehouse

16. Dana Plato

17. Whitney Houston

18. Marilyn Monroe

19. Chris Kelly

20. Heath Ledger

21. Chris Farley

22. Phyllis Hyman

23. Elvis Presley

24. Richard Pryor

25. Brittnay Murphy

26. Margaux Hemmingway

27. Jean-Michel Basquiat

story:
Hi! I'm Pontata, the owner of www.poncraftsshop.com

Firstly, a big thank you for coming to my 1st campaign!

Miracle of Life Enamel Pins is a series of 1.3"-1.5" hard enamel pins that showcases the cross section of developing eggs (and placenta) of fantasy creatures.

I had many requests to expand the Miracle of Life: Fantasy enamel pins series, but I have insufficient funds to continue after self funding 2 previous pins in the series.
 
So I will need some help in making these a reality, and that's where you come in.
 
 

 

STRETCH GOALS

 
 

Mermaid (Unlocked at S$440/$322.26USD)

  • 1.33" (3.37cm) height
  • Silver metal
  • Rubber clutch
 
 

Griffin (unlocked at S$880/$644.54USD)

  • 1.5" (3.81cm) height
  • Gold metal
  • Rubber clutch
 
 

Alicorn (Unlocked at S$1320/$966.96USD)

  • 1.5" (3.81cm) height
  • Rose Gold metal
  • Rubber clutch

 

 

Here are some examples of the past self funded pins!

 

 

Where the funds will go

 

Timeline

  • Campaign is launched 24/11/2019
  • Campaign ended 10/12/2019
  • Pin production begins 11/12/2019
  • Production of other perks begins 12/12/2019
  • Survey to backers regarding choices are sent 13/12/2019
  • Pins are received 10/1/2020
  • Pin grading, checking, preparing orders 11/1/2020
  • Final check before shipping 11/2/2020
  • Shipping begins 15/2/2020

Shipping and fulfillment

All shipping will be fulfilled by Singapore Post Registered Mail with tracking. Tracking availability is dependent on your local post office in your country.
 

Items will take 1 month to arrive from date of shipping, but it may take longer depending on different countries.

Risk and challenges

Due to the nature of enamel pins being a handcrafted item, they cannot be 100% perfect. But I will scrutinize them and send the ones best for backers.
 
There may be the possibility of delays, but I will communicate with the manufacturer to minimize the possibility.
There may be slight variations between mock up and actual pin due to pantone colours looking different on screen and slight mold shape changes.
 
If your card bounces, please contact me as soon as possible. If I do not get a reply with a week after funding, your pledge will be void.
 
Pins might be damaged during shipping, in that case please contact me via message and I will try to work out a solution best for you. I will also pack well to prevent this from happening.
 
The backer will bear additional customs, and potential import fees if applicable.
 

On a final note, if you can't pledge, spreading the word helps too! Thank you once again for visiting!

Website: www.poncraftsshop.com

~~*..-----------------..*~~
OTHER SOCIAL MEDIA
~~*..-----------------..*~~
www.instagram.com/poncrafts
www.facebook.com/poncrafts
Twitter: Potechipon

story:
MESSAGE FROM PARADE CO-FOUNDERS

Hello friends, neighbors, and art lovers! Join PARADE, a new public art program serving Queens to develop of a fantastical variety show showcasing some of Woodside’s best talent! During a two-week workshop intensive at Sunnyside Reformed Church, the artist collective Whoop Dee Doo will collaborate with local teens and arts groups from all backgrounds to create an extraordinary FREE performance for kids, adults, and possibly even dogs on August 31st at Windmuller Park! — Paddy Johnson and Nancy Kleaver

Whoop Dee Doo at the Highline, 2016

 

ABOUT THE EVENT

Whoop Dee Doo at Windmuller Park Project is a live variety show directed by the artist collective “Whoop Dee Doo,” in collaboration with local youth and community groups. In a time when human rights horrors dominate headlines around the world, a project celebrating unconditional love and difference feels more important than ever.

Using Windmuller Park and Bandshell as venue and inspiration, the project celebrates this heavily-used public space and the diverse cultures of its visitors with the people of Queens. Hosted by outlandish pop-culture inspired characters, the show will connect audiences and performers through artmaking and performance. A wide variety of surrounding arts and cultural groups will contribute “acts” and collaborate on new pieces to create a truly unique show that captures the beauty and character of the Woodside community. Current partners include McManus Irish Dance, Tibetan Community Center of NY & NJ, Woodside Dance Troupe, Bula Arts & Culture, and Queens Music Academy. Additional partners will be announced throughout the summer.

PARADE is also coordinating with local youth organizations and schools to recruit an ensemble of Queens teens to work alongside Whoop Dee Doo artists to shape the structure of the show, create original dialogue, movement, visual art, and soundscapes, perform and work backstage. The project will be a truly unique, cross-disciplinary, and crazy-creative process that's like nothing our participants will have done before, developing creative problem solving and teamwork skills.

The end result will connect diverse yet often isolated populations in this neighborhood of over 45,000 people through the artmaking and performance. Importantly, the neighborhood will also get the show of their lives—and all for free.

Windmuller Park

SUPPORT THE WINDMULLER PARK PROJECT

The Windmuller Park project is a complex production with many moving parts. With talent such as the McManus Irish Dance, Tibetan Community of NY & NJ, Woodside Dance Troupe, and Queens Music Academy secured and funds raised from the Queens Arts Council, Citizens Committee for NYC, and NYC & Co, local business sponsors, the project has exciting momentum.

The funds raised from our Indiegogo project will cover the next stage of the production: stipends for participating artists and teens, materials for sets, props, and costumes, insurance, park permits, marketing, and promotional materials, and storage and transportation.

Any funds we raise above and beyond this campaign’s goal will go towards the production, and we hope that with your help we can both meet and exceed our goal!

WHO WE ARE

PARADE is a non-profit public art program founded by arts veterans Paddy Johnson and Nancy Kleaver. We’re eager to bring public art made by the people of Queens to the borough Queens. This can take the form of park performances, theatre productions, marches, photography, public talks and all participatory forms of art.

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

The Windmuller Park Project is by far PARADE’s most challenging project to date. With our ambition, partners, and artistic talent, this project gets stronger, more exciting, and more challenging by the day.

We’re a new public art program. Our audiences are growing as are our connections with the neighborhood. But raising the money to fill gaps in our production budget continues to be a challenge.

With a combination of artist talent, incredible partners, hard work and a lot of love, this project will be a huge success. Please join us and help us raise the money we need to bring this project to life!  

WHAT YOU CAN DO TO HELP

  • Donate! We can't do this without our support! Your donations will make this show happen!
  • Spread the word! Do you or your friends want to participate? 
  • Volunteer! We need volunteers to help during our two-week art making intensive and during the event itself.

story:
Update; The remaining $350 perks are available for any time Monday morning through Wednesday night. I will remove any unclaimed perks that conflict with booked time from this page.

 
 
My name is Mike. You may know my wife Katie and I from the Vegas burner community. We built this car from the ground up this year to help our camp with transportation and to take our 1 year old son on adventures at Burning Man. Throughout the build I tried to take approaches that I had not seen in art car design before, It is all electric and uses non-traditional controls. The majority of the parts on the car are custom made involving 3d printing and machined parts on a lathe and mill. Even the lighting uses a new product from China that I have not seen used before, I think it is superior to the traditional LED strips and would like to introduce it to my fellow builders.
 

What We Need & What You Get

We are trying to raise at least $1500 towards getting the car to and from Burning Man. Any additional funds will go towards final details on the car such as speakers for the sound system, some decorative material for the bed sides, and battery upgrades. Unfortunately, due to unforeseen financial obligations we may not be able to go at all this year without a little support.

In return for your help we have stickers from our crew and are offering personal rides and playa tours. The car is available for your playa event, wedding or airport runs! Lastly, we are offering 24 hour blocks with the car. You will get a crash course on operating the car and must have a valid drivers license and be sober. If you would like to experience what Burning Man is like with your own personal art car, this is your chance!

Of course everyone is welcome to come by our camp (Contraptionists at 7:30 & E) for cold drinks and freshly shaved snow cones! We are also putting on a service to Black Rock city called "Fix Your Broken Shit". We will have a well stocked set of tools, supplies, a welder, and skilled fixers to help you fix all those things that inevitably break out there.

 

The Impact

I have been building art cars and sculptures for other designers full time for several years now but this is my first personal car. I have used everything I learned along the way in the design of this car and believe it can make a valuable contribution to the mutant vehicle community.

 

Risks & Challenges

This car is already operational and tested. As always, the playa is unpredictable and this car has not been proven in that environment yet. I do have a lot of experience with the logistics and maintenance of art cars that go to Burning Man and will have all the tools I can imagine needing for any issue that may arise.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you know someone who might be interested in one of the 24 hour blocks of time with our car or a camp that needs transportation, let them know about this campaign! We can provide airport runs, ice runs, etc. The car has a cargo bed perfect for hauling ice or luggage.

story:
Hello my friends! 

My name is Salavat Fidai. I am an artist who carves sculptures into the tips of pencils. Two years ago, I quit my high-paying executive job and became a freelance artist.  My journey begun as a creative experiment and has grown into a large signature project "Carved pencils" that became popular today. 

Many people are already familiar with my work and have added my miniatures and sculptures to their collections. 

My fans suggested I create a book about my art. This way I have the opportunity to tell you about my work and print all the art pieces I have created to date in a single edition.

Thus the idea of THE PENCILBOOK was born - a unique illustrated edition, which I have prepared especially for my subscribers.

THE PENCILBOOK contains 120 pages with 100 color illustrations of my works: Unique micro sculptures on the tips of pencils and miniatures, and an autobiography and some useful commentary. It comes in a special hardcover in a convenient square format 8.3 inch x 8.3 inch (20x20 cm).

In this book, I give some practical advice to those who want to try how to capitalize on their own talent, how to sell art on the internet.







Micro sculpture into the head of of pencils is a relatively new genre in art. It isn't often attempted as graphite is a very fragile material and the very small size of the tip itself makes things complicated. That is why, I believe, there are just a few pencil carvers all over the world, a small number that could be counted on the fingers of one hand!

Throughout the course of this year, my art has appeared in more than one hundred multilingual publications and TV Channels all over the world, including Russia, the United States, Canada, Australia, the UK, Japan, Holland, Germany and Brazil.

Featured in



It all started with my account on Instagram. At the beginning of my career, all those positive comments and advice from my subscribers helped me a lot. I have to admit that their comments keep motivating me now as well.

  Rewards

I am happy to introduce rewards that I have prepared especially for this project.

For $3 backers, I will send you an electronic PDF format version of my Pencilbook. You will also get your name on my official website as gratitude for being a backer.

For $5 backers, I will send you an original limited edition Postcard created specifically for this project and signed by ME!

For $15 backers, I will be sending you a copy of the printed THE PENCILBOOK itself, with over 100 color illustrations, an autobiography and some useful commentary. You will also get your name in the book as a gratitude for being a backer.

For $20 backers, I will be sending a limited edition of THE PENCILBOOK offered with a special cover. Each book will be signed by ME with a personalized message to the purchaser of this wonderful book.

For 40 bakers, I will sending a limited edition Art Print A2 (23.5" x 16.5") for this campaign only! You can pick any one art print from the 100+ available my art.

For collectors of rare art I have prepared a special reward: 
For all $200 backers, I will create a unique pencil sculpture just for you! The sculptures will be sent from January to March 2016. You get to choose what you want me to carve, and provided it isn't too difficult, I will do it for you!


So why do I need INDIEGOGO to publish this book? 

Many of my subscribers suggested that I create this book, so I thought "Why not?". Support from my fans and subscribers is very important to me in the creation of this project. However in order to publish this book, it will cost around $5,500USD. This amount is simply what's necessary to print this book properly on good paper, and to package it correctly, then send it safely to all the backers via post (which is really expensive).

This amount will be distributed in the following way: design, proofreading, layout preparation for publication – 10%, printing – 50%, gifts shipping costs – about 17%, taxes – 13%, crowdfunding commission and bank fees – 10%.




 I'm sure that with your support, and the help of those who have been involved in the Pencilbook project, we can make this world better.

 I want to thank everyone for supporting my campaign!
Thank you!
www.salavatfidai.com

story:
We are a group of artists participating in a network called INTAC (International Art Collaborations). This network is allowing those of us at OCAD University in Toronto, Canada to create collaborative artworks with partner universities in South Korea, Finland, Germany and Japan. We work primarily with photography and our overarching theme for the year is Revolution, with all the meanings which the word can inspire.


Each year we curate a culminating exhibition to show our final collection of works and have recently been given the opportunity to present our work in Osaka, Japan. As you might expect, this is very exciting news but the struggles of curating and organizing an international exhibition can be daunting and costly. As a result, we are hoping to fund a portion of our costs through Indiegogo while offering you a chance to own some exclusive art by some of the artists within the collective as well as our supporters.  


       Highbury, 11 x 17, Archival Digital Print, 2014. Edition of 10.

    Danya Ensing is a passionate young artist based in Toronto, Canada. She works largely with personal narratives and self-portraiture. The darkroom is her sanctuary – she has a skillful and accomplished knowledge of film and takes pride in processing and printing her own photographs whenever possible. The joy Danya finds in tactile work is pervasive in her photography as well as her interest in other mediums such as bookbinding and printmaking.  Exploring a variety of handmade processes challenges her creativity, encourages a deep understanding of craftsmanship, and diversifies her photographic practise. 

http://www.danyaensing.com/


       Refuge, 16 x 16, Archival Digital Print, 2014. Edition of 10.

   Kimberly Lee is a Toronto based artist currently studying at the Ontario College of Art and Design University (OCADU) towards a BFA in Photography. She works predominantly within the photographic medium however she also utilizes printmaking, sculpture, ceramics, book binding, and video in her practice. Her work predominantly revolves around striving to capture the beauty of the mundane, the sculptural human form, and the duality of presence and absence.

http://www.kimberlyleephotography.com/


       Mylar No.2, 16 x 16, Archival Digital Print, 2014. Edition of 10.

   Katelyn Gallucci is a Toronto based artist currently completing the fourth year in Photography at OCAD University in Toronto. Most recently she participated in, a one-day group exhibition entitled, ReMove, held inside of a Uhaul truck. ReMove investigated the guidelines around designated art space. Previously, she had the experience of assisting Lili Huston-Herterich on the construction of Herterich’s Nuit Blanche exhibition, Absolutely Free Installed at OCAD University. Gallucci’s practice uses the tools and framework of photography in collaboration with found objects to investigate how we interpret, perceive and relate to objects and space.

http://www.kmgallucci.com/


       Light Breeze, 24 x 24, Archival Digital Print, 2014. Edition of 10.

   Nick Vo is a multi-disciplinary artist based in Toronto, Canada. He is currently completing his BFA in Photography at OCAD University in Toronto, Canada. Primarily working in photography and installation, his practice explores themes of isolation, intimacy, and the ephemeral. He often uses nature as a metaphor to express these themes within the individual. Through both traditional and experimental photographic techniques, he juxtaposes them with organic processes and materials to create his works. 

http://www.nickvophoto.com/


       Sugar Beach, 26 x 26, C-Print, 2014. 

   Petar Boskovic is a Toronto-based artist working primarily in photography. He graduated from University of Toronto with a Bachelor of Arts in 2009 and is currently in his final year of Fine Arts at OCAD University. He aims to create artworks that are centred upon the individual’s relationship to his or her surroundings while often examining themes of alienation, identity, nostalgia, and the absurd. The main aspect of his work is an exploration of landscape. The attempt is to capture the visceral and peculiar elements of urban spaces, photographing images that exemplify the duality of presence and vacancy.

http://www.petarboskovic.com/


      Untitled (from In Conversation), 24 x 24, Archival Digital Print, 2012. Edition of 5.

   Sebastián Benítez is a Toronto-based artist born in Caracas, Venezuela. He explores issues of memory and identity through photography and installation. His recent works explore the role of objects and images in the construction and maintenance of notions of identity. He has participated in exhibitions in the United States, South Korea, Finland, China and Canada.

http://www.sebastianbenitez.com/



       Seven Words(abbr.) 14 x 14, Archival Digital Print, 2012. Edition of 8.

   Nathan Cyprys is an emerging interdisciplinary artist working primarily in lens based media. He is a graduate of the Ontario College of Art & Design’s Photography program and currently bases his artistic practice out of Toronto. His work is often personal as it explores the ephemeral, alienation and transitory states; always rooting itself to his own understanding of the human condition. His work has been exhibited internationally and has received recognition from the Verant Richards Scholarship, the McCain Post Graduate Residency, BlackFlash Magazine, and the Magenta Foundation’s touring exhibition, Flash Forward.

http://www.nathancyprys.com/


       Oval Tree and Walkway, 17 x 40, C-Print, 2000. Edition of 1.

   Peter Sramek studied photography at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology under Minor White and has taught at OCAD University in Toronto since 1976. He is a founding member of Gallery 44 Centre for Contemporary Photography in Toronto, one of Canada’s leading artist-run centres. Currently Sramek is Chair of Cross-disciplinary Art Practices and leads the International Art Collaborations group at OCAD U. 

His work incorporates silver photography, digital imaging, handmade books and video installation. Sramek's black and white silver photography currently exploress European historical sites and incorporates rephotographic strategies, working from historical archives. Represented by the Stephen Bulger Gallery, he is included in collections such as the Canadian Museum of Contemporary Photography, National Library of Canada, Musée Carnavalet (Paris), MOMA (NYC), Art Gallery of Hamilton, Toronto Archives and Art Gallery of Greater Victoria.    

http://www.sramek.ca/


Grab Bag
Choose from 1 or 2 prints (depending on your reward) from these selection of various images from artists within the collective.



1. KATELYN GALLUCI, Wood, 12 x 12, Archival Digital Print, 2014
2. NICK VO, Two Forks, 12 x 12, Archival Inkjet Print, 2014
3. ABIGAIL LOMBOY, Moon Landing, 12 x 12, Archival Inkjet Print, 2014
4. KIMBERLY LEE, Traces, 12 x 12, Archival Digital Print, 2014
5. DANYA ENSING, Tennent, 11 x 17, Archival Digital Print, 2014
6. PETAR BOSKOVIC, Soda Machine, 11 x 14, Archival Inkjet Print, 2014
7. MEGAN WICKENS, French Vase, 11 x 17, Archival Digital Print, 2014
8. SARDAR FARROKHI, Untitled, 11 x 17, Photograph, 2013
9. RACHEL BROMBERG, The Cycle, 11 x 17, Archival Digital Print, 2014
10. JACQUELYN HOLLAND, Pier, 11 x 14, Archival Inkjet Print, 2013

PLEASE NOTE: Most of our rewards come with additional shipping costs just so we can recover some of the money being spent on the shipping for these rewards. Thank you.

Risks & Challenges

All of the artwork rewards will be production immediately after the campaign ends in order to meet our first deadline for reward fulfillment.

Our next batch of rewards will be sent out closer to the exhibition date (or shortly afterwards) as we organize and put together the show and other rewards such as the catalogs, polaroids, etc.




We'd like to take this opportunity to thank you all of you for your time and your support!


Connect With Us:

https://www.facebook.com/INTACinfo

https://twitter.com/intacinfo

http://instagram.com/intac_ocadu_samsung/
story_txt:
We are a group of artists participating in a network called INTAC (International Art Collaborations). This network is allowing those of us at OCAD University in Toronto, Canada to create collaborative artworks with partner universities in South Korea, Finland, Germany and Japan. We work primarily with photography and our overarching theme for the year is Revolution, with all the meanings which the word can inspire.   

Each year we curate a culminating exhibition to show our final collection of works and have recently been given the opportunity to present our work in Osaka, Japan. As you might expect, this is very exciting news but the struggles of curating and organizing an international exhibition can be daunting and costly. As a result, we are hoping to fund a portion of our costs through Indiegogo while offering you a chance to own some exclusive art by some of the artists within the collective as well as our supporters.  



       Highbury, 11 x 17, Archival Digital Print, 2014. Edition of 10.    Danya Ensing is a passionate young artist based in Toronto, Canada. She works largely with personal narratives and self-portraiture. The darkroom is her sanctuary – she has a skillful and accomplished knowledge of film and takes pride in processing and printing her own photographs whenever possible. The joy Danya finds in tactile work is pervasive in her photography as well as her interest in other mediums such as bookbinding and printmaking.  Exploring a variety of handmade processes challenges her creativity, encourages a deep understanding of craftsmanship, and diversifies her photographic practise. http://www.danyaensing.com/





       Refuge, 16 x 16, Archival Digital Print, 2014. Edition of 10.   Kimberly Lee is a Toronto based artist currently studying at the Ontario College of Art and Design University (OCADU) towards a BFA in Photography. She works predominantly within the photographic medium however she also utilizes printmaking, sculpture, ceramics, book binding, and video in her practice. Her work predominantly revolves around striving to capture the beauty of the mundane, the sculptural human form, and the duality of presence and absence.http://www.kimberlyleephotography.com/




       Mylar No.2, 16 x 16, Archival Digital Print, 2014. Edition of 10.   Katelyn Gallucci is a Toronto based artist currently completing the fourth year in Photography at OCAD University in Toronto. Most recently she participated in, a one-day group exhibition entitled, ReMove, held inside of a Uhaul truck. ReMove investigated the guidelines around designated art space. Previously, she had the experience of assisting Lili Huston-Herterich on the construction of Herterich’s Nuit Blanche exhibition, Absolutely Free Installed at OCAD University. Gallucci’s practice uses the tools and framework of photography in collaboration with found objects to investigate how we interpret, perceive and relate to objects and space.http://www.kmgallucci.com/

story:
***NEWS***

The calendar reward has been cancelled. Please do not purchase that reward. Anyone who does will receive a refund. Sorry about that!

***************************************************************************************

The deck is currently 90% complete and that does not include writing the guidebook. 

SHE'S ALIVE!
I have consulted my higher self via meditation and also through tarot cards to get inspiration for messages for each card, as well as art style. Initially, I had an idea of how this deck would look, but I felt this deck has developed a mind of its own and she has been very strong at showing me people and experiences that she wants me to be influenced by and apply to the deck. I also noticed that whenever I would begin to work on a new card, I would experience the very essence of that card, and sometimes that message was a difficult one, making me realize things I hadn't noticed before. It's been a very spiritual experience creating this deck and I feel honored to be her creator. I can truly feel her energy and spirit and the messages she has to share are very powerful. She is taking me on a very profound personal growth journey!

ABOUT ME: 
I was a graphic designer for apparel for over 10 years doing graphic t-shirt designs and allover textiles that sold in Victoria's Secret, Target, Disney, JCPenney, Nordstroms, Walmart and many more. Since becoming a full-time mom 4 and a half years ago, I have been on a new spiritual journey and I have fallen in love with oracle cards. This is my third card deck, my most popular was the My Quality Time self-care activity deck which was funded last year on Kickstarter.

 

This deck was born because growing up, I had really low self-esteem and self-worth. Even now, in my mid 30's I realize, I still struggle with self-worth. I also noticed many of my friends who are well beyond their 20's and 30's, have major self-esteem and self-worth issues. This inspired me to do something about it. 

I wanted to show women how beautiful they are inside and out and how unnoticed it is by them. We often look for confirmation and validation from others that we are beautiful or worthy, but it truly has to come from the inside.

44 cards
Trump size (2.45” x 3.95”)
400 gsm matte finish
Gilding (stretch goal; color to be determined)
Magnet box (stretch goal)
Guidebook (little white booklet/deck size) includes Personal Power Affirmations, Oracle message, Journal prompts

**********NEW! There are now 3, 5 and 10 deck tiers!**************

 

PERKS:
*All backers will receive 5x7" postcards (backers will vote and choose the art)
*Stickers (if stretch goal is unlocked)
*Backers get to vote on the color edges of the cards (if stretch goal is unlocked) as well as the back designs of the cards and other things.

 

 

For Backers: Check your email for surveys to vote on the designs and to fill out your shipping information.

I will be updating this campaign to fill in the blank cards as I finish them as well as posting updates.

SHIPPING 
*If you are moving-you will be able to change your address right before your reward ships when I send out your surveys, so be sure to check your emails after the campaign.
I apologize in advance for the high shipping cost to backers who are outside of the US. That is beyond my control.

Where to find me:
Website: www.Dejadrewit.com

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/dejadrewit/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/dejadrewit/

Twitter: https://twitter.com/dejadrewit

Please contact me for a presskit: deja@dejadrewit.com

Risks and challenges

Biggest challenge is finishing the deck on time. It is only 70% finished and it's hard to predict how long it will take to finish it.

This is my third deck, but the first time I will be printing journals and calendars, I don't know if there will be any challenges with those yet. I will be printing calendars locally at a nearby printer, but I will be ordering the journals from a new company.

I will be printing calendars locally at a nearby printer, but I will be ordering the journals from a new company.

story: Ceej's troupes Franz and Dave and My Best Fiend have been accepted to the Alaska State Improv Festival in Juneau. Now Ceej could use some help with the airplane ticket, hotel and bear-related medical costs. Please chip in if you can and send a wonderful human being to Alaska.
story_txt: Ceej's troupes Franz and Dave and My Best Fiend have been accepted to the Alaska State Improv Festival in Juneau. Now Ceej could use some help with the airplane ticket, hotel and bear-related medical costs. Please chip in if you can and send a wonderful human being to Alaska.

story:
As a Miami-based artist I am aware of shifting global landscapes and how this affects the tropics of South East Florida and the global south. I am fascinated by the interconnectedness of our water systems on the planet- how melting ice on one continent will tip the balance and cause the seas to rise on another. 

My Project:

My mission is to create a cross-disciplinary project that draws from scientific research and uses ephemeral clay installations to affect a dialogue about sea level rise and its impact on the environment. It is through my unique process that I can capture a plant’s moment in time in order to recreate these delicate forms in raw clay. Collecting and casting molds of these organic forms collected in the Amazon, I will create a series of site-specific sculptures in unfired clay that will interact with Miami architecture.  It is through the ephemerality of the work and the participatory process of its creation, I wish to ultimately reference the effects of climate change and its effects on disparate landscapes. 

Through the Labverde Program, my experience at the National Institute of Amazonian Research labs will foster engagement well beyond this residency: I plan to invite my local community of artists, colleagues and students to participate in the creation of my project.

My fascination with the unseen systems in nature leads me to question how a tropical landscape can connect to other parts of the world: What issues will threaten to tip the delicate balance in different ecosystems caused by sea level rise?

What I Need & What You Get

  • The cost of the residency program is $2900. This is for ten days of workshops, field work with scientists, lectures, cultural exchange, special access to the Adolfo Ducke Forest Reserve and lodging. The flight, other travel expenses and visa cost is another $1500. I'm hoping to raise $4500. 
  • For your contributions, I am offering the opportunity to collect my ceramic artwork at a discounted price. All works are limited edition, signed and unique to it's numbered series. Endless gratitude to Pedro Wazzan for the beautiful photographs of my work!
  • I am financing this trip and the tuition for the program ahead of time- so even if I do not reach my total goal, any and all contributions will help to offset my total expenses.

The Impact

By contributing to this campaign, you help to promote awareness for impending changes to the Miami landscape through a highly unique artistic project. Although the research and collection takes place in Brazil, the actual project will ultimately end up in Miami. These ephemeral works in clay will be broken down into dry dust and recycled with water in order to build another sculpture. By eliminating the glazing and firing processes, I reduce my own carbon footprint as a ceramist, specifically from the emissions of kiln and chemical use; reclaiming and rebuilding these clay projects again and again, only to exist in memory and photographs. 

There is much we can learn from the diverse ecology of the Amazon Rainforest. Being at ground zero for sea level rise, our community is in need of artists to take an active role in creating awareness and fostering potential solutions to a changing landscape.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot help financially, you can still contribute to my cause! Please share this campaign with three people who love art and nature. 

Link to share my campaign:

Follow my journey on Facebook and Instagram.

About the Artist

Lauren is a visual artist and educator living in Miami, Florida in the United States. She earned an M.F.A. from the University of Miami and is a Visual arts faculty member at several institutions in South Florida. She has developed a multi-step casting process in clay that begins with folded origami paper as the prototypes for plaster molds, resulting in modular sculptures and installations which reference systems and visual orders found in nature. Lauren has been a resident artist at the Sanbao Ceramic Art Institute at Jingdezhen, China, where she observed and learned about post-production processes of industrial mold making and porcelain slip casting. She has exhibited during Art Basel Miami at Scope Art fair, the New Art Dealer’s Alliance (NADA) and she has showcased her work internationally during Art Basel Switzerland at Projektraum M54. Lauren is a current artist in residence at the Bakehouse Art Complex in Miami in addition to serving as Head of the Ceramics Studio. In her most recent work, Lauren is exploring ephemeral site-specific works in unfired clay and recording the subsequent decay as a metaphor for the long-term effects of climate change in landscapes.

www.laurenshapiroart.com

story:
HAPP – LE

Happiness + giggle

We are a team of four year 11 girls; Megan Hood, Juliet Kirby, Zoe Delaney and Vanessa Au-Yeung. We are all part of the One Can Grow program, which educates students about Social Enterprises and encourages them to create their own.

We have taken our love of art and combined it with the skills we have learnt in the One Can Grow program to develop an idea, which can create a more creative and happy community, in an attempt to fight against depression.

There are lots of amazing photos taken by people in their spare time but also by aspiring photographers that are not seen by the world. The Happle Project is giving you the opportunity to be acknowledged and published in our book of happiness called, "Happle". 

By creating a website where anyone can submit their photos and vote for the ones which make them the happiest we will be able to compile a book of the most popular/happiest photos.

Please join us in giving everyone the chance to be published and acknowledged for their photography!
