story:
Soutenir les Jardins réinventés !

Cet été, nous auront besoin de vous pour que l’événement artistique les Jardins réinventés de la Saint-François puisse se poursuive. La 9e édition de l’événement  permettra à des artistes multidisciplinaires  du Québec de créer des oeuvres in situ audacieuses bien enracinées dans le parc de la Rive, un site enchanteur situé à Sherbrooke, dans l'arrondissement de Brompton, et bordé par la rivière Saint-François. Quant à vous, public avide de nouveauté, vous redécouvrirez le parc sous un aspect créatif et innovant.


Les Jardins réinventés, c’est quoi?

Créé en 2008, l’événement les Jardins réinventés constitue le seul laboratoire d'expérimentation et d'innovation alliant installation in-situ et land art sur le territoire sherbrookois. Les artistes multidisciplinaires choisis sont donc invités à prendre possession d’un site extérieur pour créer une œuvre monumentale qui prend la forme d’une installation. Chaque année environ 8 installations d’envergure sont réalisées en lien avec une thématique nouvelle. 

Comme vous le savez, les Jardins réinventés connaissent un grand succès depuis déjà 8 ans. Vous êtes toujours plus nombreux à vous émerveiller devant les installations audacieuses. Malgré ce succès, il devient de plus en plus difficile avec les coupures en culture de financer cet événement artistique d'envergure.

Il est primordial de continuer à offrir un territoire de création ainsi qu'une vitrine pour les artistes, à l'extérieur des lieux institutionnels conventionnels pour que l'art puisse s'épanouir pleinement et librement. C’est également une manière de rendre l’art plus accessible, car le parc est un lieu public donc les gens vont spontanément à la rencontre des oeuvres.


Thématique 2016 des Jardins réinventés

MOUVEMENTS ET TRAJECTOIRES INSOLITES

La thématique de la 9e édition de l’événement qui inspirera les artistes cet été est Mouvements et trajectoires insolites. La Maison des arts et de la culture de Brompton, de par son emplacement, est un témoin privilégié des mouvements de la nature et de l’activité humaine, de leur évolution et trajectoire au fil du temps. L’événement Les Jardins réinventés de la Saint-François est une invitation à faire écho au lieu et à son occupation, à suggérer de nouvelles trajectoires, tantôt significatives, tantôt déroutantes. Les éléments qui nous entourent dans un parc nous sont communs et familiers. Mais, si on rêvait quelques instants d’univers déroutants, de parcours et mouvements inattendus, parfois insolites, mais toujours riches de sens?

Crédit photo Yves Harnois / Danseuse: Vicky Gagné-Vaillancourt


À quoi servira le 6000$ ?

Les artistes sélectionnés bénéficieront de 75% de la somme amassée. Le reste servira à assurer la portion logistique ainsi qu’une partie de la publicité associée à l’événement. 6000$ est le minimum à amasser pour que l'événement puisse se réaliser. 

Votre soutien est précieux

Ce projet a besoin de vous pour se poursuivre!!! En contribuant, vous encouragez et soutenez le maintien de projets culturels stimulants et originaux ainsi que leur démocratisation. Vous donnez également une vitrine ET une importance au travail des artistes professionnels d’ici et d’ailleurs. Les Jardins réinventés de la Saint-François ont grandement besoin de votre contribution!

En plus de participer à la création de cet événement artistique d’envergure, vous allez également recevoir, en échange de votre contribution, un cadeau attrayant. 


Des contreparties attrayantes!

Voici un peu de visuel pour certaines contreparties:

Crédit photo Yves Harnois / Danseuse Vicky Gagné-Vaillancourt

Visiter le site web du photographe Yves Harnois: http://yvesharnois.zenfolio.com/


Visiter le site web de l'enseignant Edgar Nzeyimana: http://www.edigar.ca/

Visiter le site web de Maude Pelletier: http://www.dessin-maudepelletier.com/


* Aucune contrepartie n'est remboursable


Comment contribuer?

Participez financièrement via Indiegogo en choisissant la contrepartie qui vous inspire à droite de la page. 

15 $, 30 $, 50$, 60 $, 65$, 80$, 100$, 125 $, 165$,  200 $, 300 $, 600$, 1000 $ et+

Peu importe le montant, toutes les contributions sont précieuses !!!

*Vous préférez un envoi par chèque ou en argent? Acheminez le montant ainsi que votre choix de contrepartie à l’adresse suivante:

                  Maison des arts et de la culture de Brompton

                  1 rue Wilfrid-Laurier

                  Sherbrooke, (Qc)

                 J1C 0P3

Pour nous aider, vous pouvez aussi faire circuler le lien de cette page dans vos réseaux.

Chaque clic contribue au positionnement stratégique de la campagne. Nous vous encourageons donc à nous aider en partageant ce lien!

Les contreparties vous seront distribuées lors de l’ouverture officielle des Jardins réinventés de la Saint-François, soit le dimanche 3 juillet à 14h. Pour ceux et celles qui ne peuvent être présents(tes) au vernissage, vous avez tout l’été pour venir chercher votre présent. 

info@maculturebrompton.com


ET MAINTENANT, QUE LE MOUVEMENT COMMENCE !

Merci en avance de votre générosité!  

Votre soutien est précieux !


Merci à tous ceux et celles qui ont rendu cette campagne possible: 

Jean-Benoit Baron, Yves Harnois, Sébastien Richer, Anne-Marie Auclair, Evelyne Papillon, Vicky Gagné Vaillancourt, Catherine Landry, Edigar Nzeyimana, Marika Roy, Maude Charland-Lallier et tous les membres du conseil d'administration du Comité arts et culture de Brompton, les studios TVA, Matv, Josée Mailloux, Chantal Paré, Walter Trudeau, Camil Gaulin ainsi que la Ville de Sherbrooke.

Visiter le site web du vidéaste Jean-Benoit Baron: https://jeanbenoitbaron.wordpress.com/

story:
Short Summary

  • Who are we? We're a group of six students studying Sculpture at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, New York. We are in our junior year and have been working since arriving at Pratt towards our junior exhibition. 
  • We've found the perfect venue in which to show our work and are funding all of our own individual projects. However, in order to reserve our space, we need to collectively pay $900 to the venue.
  • By contributing to our campaign, you will give us the chance to show New York who we are as artists and to put on an amazing show that will be the first defining point in our careers! 

What We Need & What You Get

  • What we need: We need $900 to reserve the space in which to show our work. This is already a discounted rate, as we are working in the space in exchange for a reduced cost. We are funding all of our individual projects ourselves and therefore do not have the budget to reserve the space as well without help.
  • What you get: You will be personally invited to our opening on April 29th! 

The Show

So what is this show even about?

  • We are interested in showing: objects, sculptures, installation, video, and performance work. Some themes which overlap between all of our works include heritage, personal history, body and object interaction, and hybridity of forms. 

  • As students, we have to make this happen on our own without funding from our institution. 

Risks & Challenges

A part of our requirements for the class this year is to find a place in which to host our show. If we don't raise the money and book a show, we won't meet the requirements to complete the course!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Please tell your friends and family about us.
  • You can share this indiegogo mission to your social media account.

And that's all there is to it.
story_txt:
Short Summary  
Who are we? We're a group of six students studying Sculpture at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, New York. We are in our junior year and have been working since arriving at Pratt towards our junior exhibition. 
We've found the perfect venue in which to show our work and are funding all of our own individual projects. However, in order to reserve our space, we need to collectively pay $900 to the venue. By contributing to our campaign, you will give us the chance to show New York who we are as artists and to put on an amazing show that will be the first defining point in our careers! 
   What We Need & What You Get  
What we need: We need $900 to reserve the space in which to show our work. This is already a discounted rate, as we are working in the space in exchange for a reduced cost. We are funding all of our individual projects ourselves and therefore do not have the budget to reserve the space as well without help. 
What you get: You will be personally invited to our opening on April 29th!     The Show So what is this show even about?  
We are interested in showing: objects, sculptures, installation, video, and performance work. Some themes which overlap between all of our works include heritage, personal history, body and object interaction, and hybridity of forms. 

As students, we have to make this happen on our own without funding from our institution.     Risks & Challenges A part of our requirements for the class this year is to find a place in which to host our show. If we don't raise the money and book a show, we won't meet the requirements to complete the course!
    Other Ways You Can Help If you can't contribute financially, that doesn't mean you can't help!  Please tell your friends and family about us. You can share this indiegogo mission to your social media account.   And that's all there is to it.

story:
EXCLUSIVE LAST DAYS SALE: Get the book for £12! Just donate £12 and it's yours! That also means a medium print and book for £42 and a large print and the book for £92 ! Thank you to everyone who has already contributed! 

WE need YOU in order to be able to create our FIRST photography book and to have our first exhibition ! Make this first exciting venture possible...

You are cordially invited to our first exhibition on  8 December 2015 at Safehouse 1 and 2, 137 and 139 Copeland Rd, SE15 3SN, London! This is an exciting opportunity to see our work and to collect your exclusive book showcasing our best photographs. Your presence will be greatly appreciated , we would love to see as many of you around as possible!

Who are we?  We are 17 young photographers finding our voices while studying Media and Communications at Goldsmiths. We have all chosen photography as our practice area because we are passionnate about it and want to invest in our futures in the best possible way. It is not just a hobby for us, it is what we hope and believe will stay with us as we grow old.

This coming December, from the 7th to the 9th, we will be organising our first ever exhibition together.  As you can imagine, an exhibition requires some funding. We have already found an exhibition space and have all gathered our means to be able to afford it, yet it is undeniable that as students, no matter how hard we work in our spare time to earn a bit more, we would appreciate any financial help we can get . This money will solely be used to support us in the hire of our exhibition space in South London , so that we can provide our visitors with the best possible experience. 

We have just three weeks to gather the funds and we are all faithful we can make it!

The reason why it means so much to us is that we use photography as a means of expression. We are never afraid to challenge ideas, perspectives, our viewers' emotions and intellect. In the past, we have been known to produce political work (for example immersing Calais' refugee camps to document this social and political ordeal), as well as social pieces on mental health, disease, body, and gender perception. 
We are an incredible mix of young thinkers eager to grow and to get their work seen, ranging from architecture to social documentary, not forgetting fine art photography or street photography. 

It would mean the world to us if you could help us show the world  what we see in it.

To thank you for your donations, we'll have a little gift for you: the book you helped us create, along with a medium or a large print depending on how generous you feel!


An immense thank you for visiting our page, and an even bigger to anyone who is able to help, just £1 can make a difference! You can also help us by SHARING our page on social media! Help us reach our goal and realise a dream!

Many positive photocgraphy vibes,
The GoldPhoto Squad.

story:
Introduction 

My name is Jeannette Pang, and this is my last semester at Emma Willard School. I love all forms of art, and hope to give back to the community through my work. Inspired by Brandon Stanton's Humans of New York, I decided to start Humans of Emma Willard School on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/humansofemmawillardschool). I document stories of people in the community with their portraits through the page. In less than two months, the Facebook page has gained more than 500 followers, which is the number of people currently in the school. 

Why

Emma Willard School is the first all-girls boarding school in the States. This year, my school is celebrating its bicentennial. Emma's guiding educational philosophy, known on campus as Empowerment, has taught me to be a practitioner of my passions and as a social member of the Emma community. This started out as my community art project, but because of the overwhelming support on Humans of Emma Willard School, I want to publish the site as a hardcopy book that can serve as a keepsake for everyone. The book is dedicated to Emma's Bicentennial Celebration and The Class of 2014. It will be available for sale both in school and online before graduation. 

I would really appreciate it if you could support me in making the book into reality. Thank you in advance! 

What I Need to Make the Book into Reality 

With your donation, I will be able to cover all the editing and publishing cost, and shipping fee. I will also be able to sell the book at a lower price to everyone in the community. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please read this page, share it on Facebook, and spread the word to your friends. Let art be a way we connect and keep our memories! 

Feel free to contact me with any questions you have. Again, thank you so much! 

A Sneak Peek of the Book

story:
Coming full circle

 I was born and raised in Buffalo, NY and in September, I’m going back to exhibit in the Echo Art Fair http://www.echoartfair.com/ -- a regionally notable fine art exposition -- and to speak and listen to the art students of my alma mater. And to create a project with them.

 The circle generally symbolizes wholeness, totality, unity and individuation. Coming full circle – returning to Buffalo -- for me, is an opportunity to return home, acknowledging home as a center we carry everywhere.  Recognizing actual home/place as a point of reference, I am delighted to bring the best of myself – my art – to the city where I was born and raised. I’m excited and look forward to giving back the richness of my experiences – as artist, woman, eternal student and teacher – to the students who are sitting where I once sat. In Amherst Central High School (ACHS).

 The wheel of life does not become visible until we step away from it.

 In relationship to all things, inherent in its nature, the circle connects us to ourselves and to others. However, the wheel of life does not become visible until we step away from it. In returning “home,” my vision is more varied than it was as a student and yet it is always in the process of becoming.

 When I was a student at ACHS I had the good fortune to have an inspiring art teacher who believed in me. Linda Donald. Through her, I learned to draw, experiment and begin to trust myself. Thank you Linda, wherever you are!

 My premise for this project is to be able to carry a similar light to the students. I will share some of my art experiences with them and listen to what they have to say. Together we will create something new from our encounter within the circle. If even one-person walks away inspired, my mission will be accomplished.

 Also, I would like to provide tickets for the students to attend the echo Art Fair.

 Your help in contributing funds toward this project will be used for: travel, transport to the fair, printing my photos in large format, archival museum quality, shipping, varied expenses, tickets for the fair for the students, and for my time. 

To see my work and learn more about me please go to my new website: http://www.barbaraschaefer.me/

For information about the Echo Art Fair: http://www.echoartfair.com/ 

***Please don't forget to look at the perks listed on the side. Those who choose the perks that offer drawings and paintings can choose from a selection of my work. Some examples can be seen on my other website: http://www.barbaraschaeferart.com/index.php/gallery

All perks will be sent after I return from Buffalo, around mid September.


For those unable to contribute money, please feel free to help by sharing this with others, which you can do directly from this site.

story:
Craft Kits for Kids

I am raising money to purchase supplies to make craft kits for kids at Children's Mercy Hospital. Each kit will consist of a wooden "treasure" box filled with coloring pages, stickers, decorations, and colorful pens/pencils/crayons. The kids can use the supplies to decorate the box and then keep special possessions inside. It is important for kids to feel like they have control over their environment and by having the ability to decorate something special, they can do just that. Art and craft supplies are always needed for patients because the hospital cannot clean the supplies between each patient, and are usually thrown away. 

This website says I have a goal of $500, but I am really just trying to raise as much money as possible. All money will be used to purchase the supplies and make the kits. If I don't raise $500, I will still use all the money towards supplies. 

Overall, I just want to help the kids in the hospital have control over their surroundings.

story:
Hi guys! A bit about my story...

  • Hi! I'm a Sydney based Artist  and Tattoo Apprentice..Specialising in mandalas, linework, sacred geometry, spiritual art and am moving also into dotwork. 
  • After focusing hard for the last 15 months and refining my work I have been offered a tattoo apprenticeship by Ian Cimera, Owner of Ink'd Up Guildford. I'm currently driving 2.5 - 3 hours in total to work 10 - 11 hour days, 5 days per week at the studio. As is industry standard, I don't earn any money for this until I can start tattooing. The license fee alone is $700. On top of that I still need to purchase my tattoo gear, which isn't cheap. I am surviving on the small amount of money I make from my drawings but it leaves me with no savings. So I'm asking for help to get me started so i can make a life of putting my artwork onto the skin of those who want to wear it forever. 
  • Art gives me purpose in life. There is honestly nothing more that I want to do with my life than to continue creating and growing as an artist. It would mean more to mean than one could imagine if I could just get this help that I need to kickstart my career. In return, I offer hours and hours of future work at ridiculously cheap value as a massive thank you to those who can help me out. Check out the vouchers I have on offer :)

Where your money goes and what you get for it...

  • I'm asking for $1500 but in reality I'll need about $2000... but everything helps right? The money will be going towards not only my $700 license fee but also the expensive gear I need such as a good tattoo machine for my fine lines, power supply, needles, ink etc. 
  • I am offering hours and hours of work in exchange for your help. It's also valid for 24 months from the date of when I get my license so you can either get ink'd asap or you can wait until I've had lots of practice. The hours you receive in exchange for your $ also mean you get a really good deal. 
  • If I don't reach my entire goal, I will first be putting the money I do recieve towards my license. And anything after that will be contributed towards my gear when I manage to raise the money. The vouchers are still valid whether I reach my goal or not. 

One last thing...

It would be a massive help to me if you guys could help me get this campaigne out there by sharing it for me on your social media and telling your friends. Whether you have been able to donate or not =)

Any questions, please don't hesitate to ask =)
Thank you so much! x

story:
Our Story

Our story is simple: we want to bring art supplies to the most amazing group of artists. They're incredibly talented, they're innovative, they're at the top of their field, and they happen to live in Cuba. (They're also exceptionally nice people.)

Thanks to a grant from Pratt Institute, we traveled to Cuba to research how graphic design is used in a country that does not allow commercial advertising. While there, we met with the top graphic designers and we were amazed. We learned about their process and their lives. 

We found that while they create some of the most impressive art we have seen- vibrant, bold, with incredible use of color, composition and typography- they do all of this with extremely limited supplies. Sometimes they have to redesign their pieces because they can't get the paints. They work at a printing press where the machines are literally 100 years old. And they don't have access to things that we take for granted: art journals, design catalogs, and high speed internet access to view images online.

We naively realized that there is no Blicks, no Utrecht, no four floors of Pearl Paint that they can wander. They can't just click online and have a new set of paints delivered to their door. When asked what supplies they would love to have but are hard to get, one of the artists carefully set down a sharpie and said, "this is my bible- it is very difficult to find". 

A sharpie. 

We had taken our abundance for granted. 

We decided then that the next time we returned, it would be with art supplies in tow. We thought of all of the extra supplies that were collecting dust on our shelves, or what a difference $10-20 would make.

We obtained non-profit status under the umbrella of Fractured Atlas to help encourage donations. And now we're reaching out to our friends and family, and hopefully their friends and families, to give them the opportunity to support this effort. If you can't afford a cash donation, please help by posting this on your social media. 

Thanks very much for your help!

(To view more of their work, please visit: CubanArtistsNetwork.org)

story:
Qui je suis ?

J'ai gradué en 2011 d'un DEC en design de mode et je suis un maintenant étudiant en gestion design de mode avec une concentration en études féministes à l'UQAM. Dans mes projets, je travaille beaucoup avec la question du genre et de l'identité, ce sont des sujets qui me tiennent beaucoup à coeur pour mettre l'avancement de mes idées politiques.

 

À quoi servira cette campagne ?

Cet argent me permettra de réaliser ma collection qui sera présentée lors d'une exposition à l'automne 2013. L'argent permettra de financer la réalisation de la collection.

L'exposition présentera cette collection et une autre collection, elle portera sur l'apport d'un discours philosophique au travers divers médium. Le but sera d'amener les gens à discuter au-delà du visible en sucsitant des réaction.

L'impact

Cette collection me permettra de tester mes idées politiques, mais elle permettra aussi à des jeunes étudiantes en commercialisation de la mode et réaliser un événement mode. 

C'est pour elles un des meilleurs moments pour réaliser un événement où elles auront libre court à leur imagination. C'est donc un acte pédagogique très important, d'autant plus que de travailler avec une collection originale est beaucoup plus formateur que de travailler avec des vêtements de boutique de part le dialogue artistique avec les créateurs, mais aussi de part la lattitude du dialogue.

D'autres façons d'aider

Même si vous ne pouvez pas participer, je vous invite à passer le mot sur vos réseaux sociaux parce qu'on a jamais assez de contacts !

 

Si vous avez des questions contactez moi via courriel : girard.g91@gmail.com

story:
We need your help to fund this amazing show!!! All the proceeds from the show and donations will be donated to Little City and Street Level. 

A classic sticker/street art show with a few twists in good ol' Chicago!!! Open call to any & all artists internationally to submit to the show and be featured in Chicago. Simple principle; it’s a chance for us to give back to the sticker community while exposing Chicago to some great new artists it has been missing. This will be the first sticker show that Chicago has seen in a long time and something that we are passionate and excited to bring the city this summer.

Please Send Submissions To:
MAD CITY GEMS
ATTN: ADHESIVE FIENDS
PO BOX 3291
Barrington, IL 60011
(SUBMISSION DEADLINE IS JULY 8th 2014)

Dates:
July 19th - 26th @ Paper Crown Gallery (Arlington Heights, IL)
August 1st - 15th @ Chicago Truborn (Wicker Park, Chicago)
This Fall Coming To DTLA (TBA)(Presented By: MESH)

We need your help to fund this amazing show!!! All the proceeds from the show and donations will be donated to Little City and Street Level.  
A classic sticker/street art show with a few twists in good ol' Chicago!!! Open call to any & all artists internationally to submit to the show and be featured in Chicago. Simple principle; it’s a chance for us to give back to the sticker community while exposing Chicago to some great new artists it has been missing. This will be the first sticker show that Chicago has seen in a long time and something that we are passionate and excited to bring the city this summer.

story:
We seek your support to make Nomadic Arts Festival 2014: Between Wheat & Pine the best it can be!!


What is Nomadic Arts Festival?

Nomadic Arts Festival is an experimental festival focusing on diversity, connectivity and community, through performance work and creative expression. Its nomadic nature encourages mobility, both geographically and in its form. Therefore the festival changes shape and is set in a different location each year. Each cultural, social and ecological context of every festival site shape the creative and artistic theme of each festival – attempting to create a mobile community of sharing, creativity, research, exploration and fluidity.

This year the festival will take place in two locations in Poland: Warsaw and Charciabałda. The latter is more specifically an “off-grid” farm, in north-east Poland, located at an old wheat field, set between pine forests, of which the 2014 festival has taken its name and theme.

The festival at Charciabałda, will therefore be a two day intimate gathering, set ‘Between Wheat & Pine’ with focus on the proximity and relationship with the surrounding environment. It will be a small community with collective dinners, workshops, regional folk dance and performances from international artists, exploring the diversity of the theme ‘Body & Earth’

In Warsaw, Nomadic Arts Festival, in Collaboration with In Situ Foundation, Pracownia Zelazna will present a two day performance event, gathering performance and live art from the transnational communities of performance makers, across Poland. It will be two busy days with a wide range of experimental performances.


In Situ Foundation


Pracownia Zelazna

Burdąg Foundation


Program


The 2014 program will be a mixture of national and international performances, all dealing with the theme 'Body & Earth'. Here is a selection of the artist for the 2014 program:

RED BIND (Toulouse) with RED POLE DANCE
www.kedzior-­‐friedman.org

Alfie, Ben and Stefan (London, Bristol, Göteborg) with From here Dotąd
walkingfromheretothere.wordpress.com

Anna Haracz, Dana Chmielewska and Agata Gregorkiewicz (from across Poland) with Would you walk with me?
www.dialogotancu.com.pl

Karolina Kubik (Poznan) with Untitled (Wound. Landscape units, related with observations and conquest, through the rhetorics of human body)
Site Specific Performance working with the local community.

Wahshi Kuhi (Iran/Kurdistan/ Berlin) with My father was an oak tree in Marivan! The army burned him down. My mother was dried. and me...
http://wiryabudaghi.wordpress.com

Supi (Oxford, England) with THE EARTH’S EMBRACE  (Ancient Burial Ritual)
www.suepennington.com

AND THERE ARE MORE ARTISTS YET TO COME!

OUR TARGET

We have created this campaign to ask for your support to raise money and make Nomadic Arts Festival the best it can be. We need your help to reach our target of €2000 (and beyond!) in order to cover the last basic expenses of the festival:


-Festival materials       
-Documentation
-Transportation to and from Warsaw and the festival site

But we hope to raise more!

This is why:

The festival is run voluntarily and we have done our best to keep our costs as low as possible, yet we feel we have a responsibility towards the artists who are presenting work at the festival. So far we have only been able to cover their travel costs, which means that all the artists are working voluntarily, which warms our hearts, as it means that they believe in the ethos and ideas behind the festival. Though as an organisation we do feel committed to make the best attempt in supporting the artists, both artistically and financially. The money we raise during this campaign, which exceeds our target, will therefore go exclusively to the artists presenting work at the festival - divided equally between them.


Background and Ethos

‘the nomad is a […] intensive, multiple entity,
functioning in a net of interconnections […]
the site of multiple connections.’

-Rosi Braidotti (Nomadic Subject)

The festival has grown out of an ecological desire to use the realm of the arts for research, sharing and creativity, whereby to explore and draw focus to the specificities of local, cultural and geographical contexts. Similarly being nomadic by nature, the festival also puts an emphasis on creating intercultural and transnational communities. Focusing on sharing as a key ethos for learning, developing and exploring, the festival therefore aims to set up temporary communities throughout the world, where connections, relation and exchanges are facilitated.

The artists are the backbone of the festival and it is them who offers the opportunity for people to get together. Their sharing of research and explorations gives colours to the festival, but furthermore create a scope into the theme each festival presents, as a body of research of that theme, which will culminate in a documentation of the festival. So the festival both have an emphasis as an arts festival celebrating cultures, communities and the value of Live Art, but also functions as an exploration and research into themes, as an aim to shed new light on human and ecological conditions and issues of living in our contemporary world.

Other Partners and Associates


Nomadic Village



Give & Get



TaniecPolska

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell all your friends and spread the word on social medias, emails and word of month. Any help would be warmly appreciated!!

Also join our facebook site and twitter and visit our website:

www.nomadicartsfestival.com

www.facebook.com/nomadicartsfestival

twitter.com/NomadicArtsFest

story:
Short Summary

Hello Everyone,

          Thanks for taking a moment to stop by my project and check it out. My name is David Wahlman, I'm a senior at Biola University in L.A. and will be graduating in December. As part of my culmination as a Bachelor of Fine Arts student, I must put on a gallery showing of my art. For me, my art medium is photography. 

          With my photography, I'm love using dramatic, artificial lighting and I love telling stories, creating narrative, or having a distinct point to be made with my art. Much of my style-inspiration is from Gregory Crewdson. In this specific show, I will be creating a series with a central theme or lesson to be learned. I will be filling the entire gallery by myself and will be doing so with 12-15 pictures. Each photo is going to be it's own unique scenario and will be printed and framed at 4' x 5' (really large). I will be printing them myself on a large-format printer, building my own frames, and basically doing all the labor and setup myself. It is these costs (printing, paper, wood supplies, etc.) that will be expensive. Printing at 4 foot by 5 foot is no cheap thing and wood isn't always the cheapest either, not to mention the little miscellaneous costs. 

         By contributing, you make this magnitude of a show possible for me. Without the proper funding, I will most likely have to settle with less than grand by reducing sizes, image qualities, and overall show grandeur. The show will be hosted in a gallery open to all the university and to public, meaning it will be seen by hundreds of people and I don't want to put out anything but my best. Your help will make this show possible.

What I Need

          Alright, let me break down what I'm needing and where the funds will be going: 

- Each photo is going to cost about $80 in ink and paper to print (I said $50 in the video. Oops). Since I'm likely doing 15 prints, that's about $1,200 already. 
- Each of the frames requires 1/8in plexi-glass which I'll be able to get in bulk. Each 4x5' sheet breaks down to about $100 which again gives me about $1,500 (100 x 15 = 1,500)
- Then to build my own frames, the only cost thankfully will be the wood. I'll be getting the planks of hard-wood from a lumber yard and then cutting and building myself. The total of wood is still unsure, but I'm guessing from prices I've seen, it will be about $300-400 total.

- I already own my own professional gear, so there shouldn't be any costs there unless I need to do something very specific where I must rent a piece of gear. So I'm not including that in my goal estimate. 


Any and all funds raised will be essential towards making this show happen. No money will go unused and no contribution will go unnoticed. I can use anything you are willing to give. The more money that is raised, the more it allows me to produce a professional, beautiful, show with quality work. 


    Risks & Challenges

              I am already the prime example of a college student and starving artist (lol). I am trying to make ends meet, paying for college, for rent, for food, and then you add the cost of a $3,000 show in the matter of two months and I won't be able to handle it. The only way to make the show happen if I have no money is to cut corners on the quality of the show (using a cheaper wood, not as quality of a plexi-glass, less images, or not printing as large). All of the shortcuts are ones that I don't want to have to do. I want to put up something I'm proud of, something that is quality, and something that displays my talents as a creative and a photographer.


      Other Ways You Can Help

      Some of you may not be able to contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

      - Please share this project on all your social media and get the word out. The more people that know about it, the more potential there is for reaching my goal.
      - If you should like, your personal encouragement would also be greatly appreciated!
      - If you don't want to give, but you have resources that may be beneficial to me, I'd love to hear about those as well. For example, if you have acres and acres of land that I could use to do a photo-shoot, if you have professional camera or lighting equipment you'd allow me to temporarily use, if you own a lumber yard of high quality hard-woods and would like to offer the wood, etc, etc, etc, etc....



      Any way you can help will be GREATLY appreciated! Thanks for taking the time to read and consider helping me.

Thanks for taking the time to read and consider helping me.

story:
Our Story

Hola! Gabriel San Roman and Carla Zarate have joined forces as co-creators of the Subversive Historian’s 2015 ‘Calendar of Revolt’ project! We have undertaken this endeavor to present a new way of highlighting history in an accessible manner. The “Subversive Historian” morphs from its origin as a daily radio segment as heard for years on KPFK-Pacifica Radio in Los Angeles into 12-months of radical history! The ‘Calendar of Revolt’ combines the rebellious spirit of slingshot pocket organizers with an artistic aesthetic that a calendar brings while providing historical quotes of inspiration. It focuses on the emancipation struggles of workers, radicals, women, people of color, and the LGBT community throughout the history of the United States and elsewhere.

Gabriel San Roman is the “Subversive Historian” and also multimedia journalist whose work has been featured on KPFK Radio and in the pages of OC Weekly, ZMagazine, and online at Truth Out in addition to numerous other outlets. He’s also the author of “Venceremos: Victor Jara and the New Song Movement” published by PM Press.

Carla Zarate is the designer of the ‘Calendar of Revolt.’ Originally from Mexicali, Mexico, she was a producer, camera woman and documentary directory before becoming a part of SolArt Gallery, a collective promoting solidarity through ALL the arts in Santa Ana CA. Since then, Zarate’s been busy creating graphic design for non-profit organizations, documenting the Latin Alternative music scene, producing videos, collaborating with artists on public art.

The Impact

The Subversive Historian’s 2015 ‘Calendar of Revolt’ holds faithful to its mission of providing daily histories that have otherwise remained “mysteries.” It's a rhyming nod to the fact that obscuring stories of injustice and resistance to it in the United States and beyond frames establishment history. This has been on display in Tucson, Arizona and Texas before it where critical literature has been banned in the former and textbooks have been subject to ideological revisions in the latter. To hell with that, we say!

What We Need & What You Get

This campaign is primarily aimed at covering the printing costs for the Calendar of Revolt. Carla and Gabriel will be collaborating with socially conscious printers and distributors in making the world a more righteous place. What do you get? Aside from the knowledge and inspiration rulers 'round the world would rather you not have, check out our pledge level perks!

Other Ways You Can Help

Friends, family, comrades, and truth professors!

Help Carla and Gabriel out by promoting our campaign through word of mouth and all your social networking! Share this page on Facebook. Tweet it. Do whatever you can. Give whatever you can. Hell, go ahead and tell a reactionary conservative about our project! All your support is warmly appreciated and we won’t let you down! And remember: It’s no mystery why they conceal our people’s history! Spread the word and the truth!

Carla Zarate and Gabriel San Roman

story:
Hello friends!

I'm so delighted to share the joy of my pregnancy with the whole world, since I've been wishing to be a mother ever since I can remember. I will be traveling home to California (from Portland, Maine) to be with family and old friends when I give birth.




The Trip:

Quite synchronistically, my soul tribe is also leaving Maine at the same time, to slow-travel around the world, under the moniker Travel by YES! We'll be caravanning together across the country, while offering our passions of getting people playing and making art. The team has plans to offer our own line of adventure gear, virtual games, real-life retreats, roadside parties, etc. It'll be the adventure of a lifetime!


What I'm asking for:

I am asking for the funds to buy my own car to travel in across the country. While there's other ways to get from here to there (as I discovered first-hand a year ago when I traveled east by bike and ride-share), I feel that one of the best investments I could make at this time would be in my own vehicle, which can serve me for years to come. This car will allow me great comfort as my pregnancy progresses while I'm on the road, and it'll be an amazing resource once I land in California. I'm also excited to offer ride-shares and pick up hitchhikers, returning the favor I've been on the receiving end of so many times. I have my eye on craigslist cars for under $2,000. I feel that $5,000 will easily allow me to buy a used car, insurance, fuel, and will give me a comfy fund to buy myself the best foods to support the new life growing inside of me.

Whatever I raise beyond $5,000 will become a nesting fund to support me in my landing once I reach California. My father and I would like to join or form a co-operative house in the Bay Area, where we'll be joined by the baby's father, Leaf, and any extra money will go towards funding this new nest, as well as anything needed for the darling new life, Ruby.

 

How your donation creates lasting support:

The "perks", or as I like to call them, presents, that I'm offering for the different levels of donations are things I am proud and excited to offer. I have become an adept and passionate seamstress over the past several years, and I am offering a variety of sewn art goodies as the presents. I will continually offer these products on my own Etsy account. So, when you receive your art present for donating, whenever anyone comments on your treasure, you can refer them to my Etsy. I'm excited to learn what really resonates with people, and to have a blossoming, independent art business that I can support myself with. I'm SO excited to be traveling, and sewing these gifts with so much love, pouring appreciation into every stitch, knowing that it's going towards someone who helped make my trip possible.

The wider effect:

While I'll be working on creating art to send to people in the mail, I will also be creating and facilitating collaborative art making environments across the country. Travel by YES! has plans to set up art parties in parks, in studios, on beaches, at festivals. Wherever we are, we'll be inviting the world to play with us. I've done this many times in the past, in homes, cafes, galleries, and parks. The launch party for this campaign will have several collaborative art projects to play in. I see this form of group collaboration as one of the most exciting ways to invite people to play in harmony: when we feel free to creatively express ourselves, we can understand each other in new ways and celebrate each other's genius and unique beauty.

Pictures of the Presents:

The first embroidered name of a supporter on my mama hood dress (Joe):

Hannah and Leaf, the main musicians featured on the lullaby-folk song album, as well as Ruby's delighted parents:

Some examples of treasures that might make up your nest-box (not pictured: the unique hand-sewn baby doll who will be tucked inside the nest). These were all collected from the Portland, Maine shore during low tide:

Here's a piece of art made especially for this pregnancy by Christine O'Hara, which will be included in the Book for Ruby.


An example notebook's front cover, and opened to a random page. Yours, of course, will be custom-made to your preferences:

A potential design for a tapestry or quilt:
story_txt: Hello friends!I'm so delighted to share the joy of my pregnancy with the whole world, since I've been wishing to be a mother ever since I can remember. I will be traveling home to California (from Portland, Maine) to be with family and old friends when I give birth.The Trip:Quite synchronistically, my soul tribe is also leaving Maine at the same time, to slow-travel around the world, under the moniker Travel by YES! We'll be caravanning together across the country, while offering our passions of getting people playing and making art. The team has plans to offer our own line of adventure gear, virtual games, real-life retreats, roadside parties, etc. It'll be the adventure of a lifetime!What I'm asking for:I am asking for the funds to buy my own car to travel in across the country. While there's other ways to get from here to there (as I discovered first-hand a year ago when I traveled east by bike and ride-share), I feel that one of the best investments I could make at this time would be in my own vehicle, which can serve me for years to come. This car will allow me great comfort as my pregnancy progresses while I'm on the road, and it'll be an amazing resource once I land in California. I'm also excited to offer ride-shares and pick up hitchhikers, returning the favor I've been on the receiving end of so many times. I have my eye on craigslist cars for under $2,000. I feel that $5,000 will easily allow me to buy a used car, insurance, fuel, and will give me a comfy fund to buy myself the best foods to support the new life growing inside of me.Whatever I raise beyond $5,000 will become a nesting fund to support me in my landing once I reach California. My father and I would like to join or form a co-operative house in the Bay Area, where we'll be joined by the baby's father, Leaf, and any extra money will go towards funding this new nest, as well as anything needed for the darling new life, Ruby. How your donation creates lasting support:The "perks", or as I like to call them, presents, that I'm offering for the different levels of donations are things I am proud and excited to offer. I have become an adept and passionate seamstress over the past several years, and I am offering a variety of sewn art goodies as the presents. I will continually offer these products on my own Etsy account. So, when you receive your art present for donating, whenever anyone comments on your treasure, you can refer them to my Etsy. I'm excited to learn what really resonates with people, and to have a blossoming, independent art business that I can support myself with. I'm SO excited to be traveling, and sewing these gifts with so much love, pouring appreciation into every stitch, knowing that it's going towards someone who helped make my trip possible.The wider effect:While I'll be working on creating art to send to people in the mail, I will also be creating and facilitating collaborative art making environments across the country. Travel by YES! has plans to set up art parties in parks, in studios, on beaches, at festivals. Wherever we are, we'll be inviting the world to play with us. I've done this many times in the past, in homes, cafes, galleries, and parks. The launch party for this campaign will have several collaborative art projects to play in. I see this form of group collaboration as one of the most exciting ways to invite people to play in harmony: when we feel free to creatively express ourselves, we can understand each other in new ways and celebrate each other's genius and unique beauty.Pictures of the Presents:The first embroidered name of a supporter on my mama hood dress (Joe):Hannah and Leaf, the main musicians featured on the lullaby-folk song album, as well as Ruby's delighted parents:Some examples of treasures that might make up your nest-box (not pictured: the unique hand-sewn baby doll who will be tucked inside the nest). These were all collected from the Portland, Maine shore during low tide:Here's a piece of art made especially for this pregnancy by Christine O'Hara, which will be included in the Book for Ruby.An example notebook's front cover, and opened to a random page. Yours, of course, will be custom-made to your preferences:A potential design for a tapestry or quilt:

story:
IN THE PRESS

                                    

                            

                        

             


               

    

             

                                                                                                                                   

                                         

                                                      

                                                                                                                                                                                         

                                     

                         

                              


                                                                                                                                                   

OUR STORY

We are David Puig and Manar Moursi, authors of Sidewalk Salon: 1001 Street Chairs of Cairo, a unique photographic documentation of original street chair designs that dot the sidewalks of Cairo and create an alternate portrait of the city through their lens.

We first took notice of the street chairs of Cairo in 2011, walking on Port Said Avenue, which straddles the city from North to South. “A funny thing about a chair: you hardly ever think it’s there”, the American poet Theodore Roethke once wrote. And yet that day, all of a sudden, those street chairs were there. Not one or two of them, isolated, but one after the other creating some kind of invisible thread along the sidewalk.

Repaired, stitched and embellished, those chairs age graciously despite being constantly on duty outdoors. The curiosity triggered by these common objects made us realize how essential they were to the everyday life of people who spend a considerable amount of time on the sidewalk. We realized we could understand Cairo and tell some of its stories from the perspective of those street chairs. 

Over the past 3 years we’ve collected more than a 1000 Polaroid images of the street chairs of Cairo as well as interviews with their owners. We’ve commissioned fiction and poetry inspired by street chairs to award winning writers from the city. In the past few months we’ve gone through a rigorous process of selecting and arranging those images in a book format. We have been working with the very talented Dutch Graphic Designer Sandra Kassenaar to create the visual identity of our book. Preview the book here: http://issuu.com/manarmorsi/docs/sidewalk_salon...

We are now almost ready to print Sidewalk Salon: 1001 Street Chairs of Cairo, and you can now join us on our journey through the streets of Cairo, and wander with us in the alleys of what we call "the biggest open-air chair museum of the world."

WHAT WE NEED

Since Sidewalk Salon: 1001 Street Chairs of Cairo is a full-color art book, its production and printing are expensive. Our goal is to have a publication of the finest quality available at an affordable price in Egypt and the rest of the world. We will be co-publishing our book with independent publishers from Europe and Egypt. Small independent publishers do a great job to give exposure and to distribute interesting projects like ours but have limited resources for their production. Your contribution to our campaign goes straight into the project, to cover final editing, agencies licenses, finalizing design, printing and shipping costs. With your support, we will be able to launch a first print edition of at least a thousand copies the book, and you will have your very own copy, as well as some other exclusive perks from our list!

For more info, check out the diagram below:


WHAT YOU GET

To thank you for your help we have prepared some very special perks that you will find in the right-hand column of this page. Many of our perks have been exclusively designed for this campaign. We are also offering artworks related to the campaign by some of our favorite Egyptian and international contemporary artists. No additional fees will be charged for the shipping of the perks.

ABOUT US

David Puig is a diplomat, translator and publisher from the Dominican Republic. He has worked in France, India and Egypt. In 2010, he launched Ediciones De a Poco, a publishing house focused on contemporary literature and art books from the Caribbean region. While in Delhi, he collaborated with Vislumbres, a literary magazine which brings together Latin American and Indian writers. His published translations to Spanish include the novel Les dollars des sables by Jean-Noel Pancrazi.

Manar Moursi’s work spans the fields of architecture, urbanism, design and art. In 2011, Manar founded Studio Meem (www.studiomeem.me) an interdisciplinary design studio based in Cairo. In 2014, in recognition of Manar’s architectural design work for Studio Meem, she received the ArcVision Women in Architecture Award. In addition to architecture, Studio Meem’s practice encompasses product design work.  In 2012 Studio Meem’s inaugural product line Off the Gireed, inspired by everyday street objects in Cairo, was awarded a Red Dot and a Good Design Award. Further to design work, Manar has worked on multiple art projects, the latest being a series of public art installations titled the “Wonder Box”. Her latest photography exhibition was shown at the Contemporary Image Collective in Cairo. It traveled regionally as part of a group exhibition titled “Next to Here” - curated by Constanze Wicke. Manar’s writings on urban issues have appeared in Thresholds, Lunch, Magaz and Al Masry El Yowm.

Indiegogo campaign video: Aida El Kashef

Music for the Indiegogo video: Aya Metwally

WHAT PEOPLE SAY ABOUT OUR PROJECT

"A chair is a container that frames the human body presenting its greatness or fragility. Whether on a throne or stool we are all united in our act of sitting, resting, or in the pausing of energy. This book is a collective moment of, a much-needed, stillness and contemplation from a nation that has been in perpetual motion for over three years. Moving away from the metaphorical chair of power that dominates Egyptian authoritarianism, it presents portraits of mundane chairs, as silent commentators, narrating an overlooked but meaningful aspect of a nation’s urban existence." Basma Hamdy, Artist, designer and assistant professor at VCU Qatar. Co-author of Walls of Freedom.

“Cairo is a city that rarely runs on straight lines - instead it's a patchwork quilt of semi-hidden and contested spaces, and you can find a dusty street chair in every one of them. Manar and David have chosen a unique and alternative lens through which to explore the capital, and I can't wait to see the printed book.” Jack Shenker, Journalist and author currently working on a book exploring Egypt and resistance, to be published by Allen Lane and Penguin in 2015.

“Sidewalk Salon is a beautiful collection of stories presenting fragments of life in Cairo though one of the city's most ubiquitous inanimate objects, the street chair.” Mohamed El Shahed, Founder and editor, Cairo Observer.

“If you’ve been to Cairo, you've probably wandered by more than a few repurposed, decrepit, charmingly Frankensteinian street chairs. Moursi and Puig spent years painstakingly documenting, mapping, and carefully curating these chairs for Sidewalk Salon, a beautiful ode to these inadvertent objects of art and the denizens who created them. In broad terms, the book is a journey through the last few tumultuous years of Cairo's history; but more specifically it is a tale about Egyptians—their struggle, passion, humor, and endurance—a story which unfolds as a walking tour of a fragmented city where conflict is rooted in the movement and reclamation of public space, the front lines of which are occupied by these fascinating chairs. This book is evidence that the streets, at least, are still in the hands of the people.” Yasmin Elayat, New media artist, interaction designer and technical director at Second Story.

“An invaluable project romanticizing the seemingly mundane, vividly illustrating the intricate and complex social landscapes of Cairo in the process. Posterity will look kindly upon the work of Moursi and Puig.” Joobin Bekhrad, Founder and editor, Reorient.

“Manar Moursi and David Puig's Sidewalk Salon engages Cairo through the ubiquity of its street chairs: each chair tells a unique story, together they create a complex and quirky portrait of Cairo's public spaces.” Beth Stryker, co-founder CLUSTER (Cairo Lab for Urban Studies, Training, and Environmental Research)

“Sidewalk Salon is an outstanding documentation of everyday ingenuity and creative adhocism, as displayed through a series of chairs, half ready-made and half invented to fit local and temporal needs of Cairo's citizens. The book showcases not only the remarkable traits of local craftsmanship, but also the material marks of a culture in revolt as manifest in urban space.” Lydia Kallipoliti, Assistant professor of architecture at Syracuse University and principal of EcoRedux Research Network and ANAcycle studio.

"An interesting and unique project I was lucky enough to take part in. This book documents a side of Cairo life that visitors and residents see every day but almost never take note of." Adam Talib, Assistant professor at the American University of Cairo and literary translator.

PERKS

We've created a reference diagram below with all the perks we are offering you! Please select a category from below. If your perk includes options (marked with a star) please follow the instructions below this diagram. If you are not interested in getting a perk,  but would still like to contribute to our campaign, you can simply select any category on the right then click "change perks" and pick the "no perk" option.

HOW TO CHOOSE YOUR PERK : 

(only applies to perks that included options marked with a yellow star):

If you choose a perk with a postcard, poster, tote bag, digital print, original artwork you may select from below:

  1. Choose your perk category from the list above.
  2. Look at the list below and check for the CODE that corresponds with your choice.
  3. After you select your perk and enter your details, type the CODE corresponding to your choice in between brackets following your STREET ADDRESS. 
  4. PLEASE NOTE: if you do not enter a CODE we cannot guarantee your choices. Please email us the code if you forget to include it.

For questions send us an email at 1001chairscairo@gmail.com


Below are more detailed images of each of our perks with a clearer description.







OTHER WAYS TO SUPPORT US

There are many ways in which you can help and support us!

If you can’t give money to our campaign there’s still lots you can do for Sidewalk Salon: 1001 Street Chairs of Cairo.

We need people around you to know about our project and you can become an ambassador of our campaign. Follow us and stay tuned for details: tweet about us, like us on Facebook, or write a blog post. Let people know what we are doing! Thanks for helping us get the word out.

Here's the short link again to our campaign: bit.ly/sidewalksalon

And our website: www.sidewalksaloncairo.com

You can also follow us on Facebook and Twitter!

https://twitter.com/1001chairscairo
https://www.facebook.com/1001streetchairscairo

story:
The Southside Battletrain is South Minneapolis builders, welders, engineers, artists, and neighbors who collaborate to create interactive art spectacles for and by the community. Our project began in 2008 as a pedal-powered Ice-Fishing Shanty, and is now a human-powered train seven cars long.  We are asking you for support of this evolving project, which has become an eagerly anticipated highlight of each year’s parade.

  This is our seventh year of participating in the Heart of the Beast's May Day Parade and Celebration.  Over 50,000 people from the Twin Cities and beyond gather every year to celebrate the coming of spring with the parade and festival in Powderhorn Park, now in its 41st year (hobt.org/mayday).

  Every year we push the limit to top our prior creation of human-powered trailers and floats. Last year we built a 3-carriage Human-Powered Ferris Wheel! It is 21 feet tall. Our “Pedaled Train” consists of floats carrying live music, cooking, shelter and spectacles.

  This year we are building the Southside Schooner, a sunken ship on wheels that will have aerial performers dangling from its mast. The ship will be patterned on Minnesota's historic schooner, the Samuel P. Ely, which sank off the shores of Two Harbors on October 30, 1896. The Southside Schooner will join the Battletrain along with the Pedal Cloud (a 10-person bicycle), the Caged Skate Ramp, the Human-Powered Ferris Wheel, the Shanty and the Grill Trailer (used to cook food we pass out for free).

  We are asking you for support for our material costs and expenses for the build-space. For example:

  • $20 pays for safety glasses and cut-off wheels
  • $50 refills 2-3 propane tanks
  • $100 pays for welding gas
  • $200 buys the lamb

All of our participation is passion based; we do not get paid for our involvement. Not only does it take many hands to build a mobile Caged Skate Ramp or a Ferris Wheel, it takes just as many people to transport, manipulate, and enjoy them.  Eighty-seven people (87!) were part of our parade crew last year. 

Thank you for your donation and please spread the word!

WORKSHOPS! Come by and check us out, get to know us.
Bring ideas, skills, questions, food, time, hands, excitement. Workshops will be taking place in April and will be at 3100 Portland Ave S in the GARAGE. More info TBA!

story:
Bring the Hippie Toilet to Burning Man 2014!

Hippie Toilet was an interactive art installation for the Burning Man Regional event known as SOAK.  The installation was completed and available for participation at the festival between July 10th – 24th, 2014.

At the festival man people came up to me and told me how they loved the project and asked if I was going to be taking it to Burning Man this year.  The short answer, is:  MAYBE...

The project consisted of a large (14′) trampoline frame covered in white stretch fabric that sloped down to a 6″ hole in the middle. Balls are provided on the outside that can be rolled by participants on the surface of the fabric “cone”. As the balls roll they interact with each other and bend the surface of the fabric causing other interactions. The entire piece is lit with colorful lighting and black lights which make the balls glow and cause ‘tracer’ effects as they move. Once the balls fall into the middle hole they are returned to the outside of the piece to be used again.

The project actually ended up being much more expensive to build than originally anticipated and I just don't have the funds to get to Burning Man with it.  However, since there was so many people that encouraged me to find a way to bring it to Burning Man this year, I've decided to launch a crowd sourced funding to try and do just that!  YOUR CONTRIBUTION WILL MAKE IT POSSIBLE TO BRING THIS ART TO THE PLAYA!

What We Need

To bring the Hippie Toilet to the Playa that the project must raise at least $780 to be able to make it to the Playa and the Black Rock Arts Festival.  This covers transportation, fuel, and other basic costs.  After those costs additional funding would be used to improve several parts of the project. 

Things I'd like to do to improve the installation for Burning Man:

  • Improve the ball return to be more reliable and sturdy - $100
  • Build a box to hide the generator, battery, and controller for the project. - $100
  • Add more powerful UV lights - $500
  • Build a sensor that detects when balls drop through the opening and have this trigger changes in the lighting. - $200
  • Setup a simple time lapse camera to document people interacting with the piece through the festival. - $100

What You Get

Your donations will :

  • Help to fund bringing the Hippie Toilet to Burning Man!
  • Get you cool perks including cool bouncy balls, signed art prints, personalized thank you cards, and even a miniature version of the art piece for yourself.
  • Help to improve the installation to make it even more impressive and interactive!

Risks & Challenges

There are several risks to this project but they are pretty minimal since the majority of the risk and challenges have already been worked out.  As a veteran Burner, the risk of my not making it or having problems on Playa is minimal.  However, there could be transpiration issues, unexpected repairs, or the worse case scenario the stretch fabric piece is torn or damaged.  Another risk could be a failure of the lighting system on playa.  I'm going to try and minimize that possibility by all the electronics and the lights being sealed in clear plastic bags, and by shading the controller and power system during the day.

But the biggest risk is that I cannot find a ticket or that we do not even raise the $780 I need as a minimum to bring this project to the Playa.  However, since I am well connected in the local community I am not worried about finding a ticket for sale, and more worried about raising enough money to cover costs.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute even $5?  That is okay, here is some other ways you can help:

  • Get the word out and share this campaign on FaceBook, Twitter, and other social media!
  • Indiegogo provides share tool., so just click and share!
  • If you can think of any other ways to help, please don't hesitate to contact me.

THANKS AND I HOPE TO SEE YOU ON PLAYA PLAYING WITH MY BALLS!
story_txt:
Bring the Hippie Toilet to Burning Man 2014! 
Hippie Toilet was an interactive art installation for the Burning Man
 Regional event known as SOAK.  The installation was completed and 
available for participation at the festival between July 10th – 24th, 
2014.
At the festival man people came up to me and told me how they loved the project and asked if I was going to be taking it to Burning Man this year.  The short answer, is:  MAYBE...
The project consisted of a large (14′) trampoline frame covered in 
white stretch fabric that sloped down to a 6″ hole in the middle. Balls 
are provided on the outside that can be rolled by participants on the 
surface of the fabric “cone”. As the balls roll they interact with each 
other and bend the surface of the fabric causing other interactions. The
 entire piece is lit with colorful lighting and black lights which make 
the balls glow and cause ‘tracer’ effects as they move. Once the balls 
fall into the middle hole they are returned to the outside of the piece 
to be used again.
The project actually ended up being much more expensive to build than originally anticipated and I just don't have the funds to get to Burning Man with it.  However, since there was so many people that encouraged me to find a way to bring it to Burning Man this year, I've decided to launch a crowd sourced funding to try and do just that!  YOUR CONTRIBUTION WILL MAKE IT POSSIBLE TO BRING THIS ART TO THE PLAYA!

Improve the ball return to be more reliable and sturdy - $100
Build a box to hide the generator, battery, and controller for the project. - $100
Add more powerful UV lights - $500 Build a sensor that detects when balls drop through the opening and have this trigger changes in the lighting. - $200
Setup a simple time lapse camera to document people interacting with the piece through the festival. - $100

Help to fund bringing the Hippie Toilet to Burning Man!
Get you cool perks including cool bouncy balls, signed art prints, personalized thank you cards, and even a miniature version of the art piece for yourself.
Help to improve the installation to make it even more impressive and interactive!

But the biggest risk is that I cannot find a ticket or that we do not even raise the $780 I need as a minimum to bring this project to the Playa.  However, since I am well connected in the local community I am not worried about finding a ticket for sale, and more worried about raising enough money to cover costs.
Other Ways You Can Help
 Can't contribute even $5?  That is okay, here is some other ways you can help: 
Get the word out and share this campaign on FaceBook, Twitter, and other social media! Indiegogo provides share tool., so just click and share!
If you can think of any other ways to help, please don't hesitate to contact me. 
 THANKS AND I HOPE TO SEE YOU ON PLAYA PLAYING WITH MY BALLS!

story:
Billions of Candlepower on the Playa

Join in the sheer enjoyment of human interaction with amazing beams of pure light.

Project Flashlight is billion-candlepower (really!) beams that you control with an amplified light saber or a tablet.  These things are the brightest searchlights ever made, visible from space.  On playa for art and fun.

In 2013 we had 2 searchlights at 11:00 in deep playa with tablet controls.  Maybe you saw us?

For 2014 we'll bring 4 searchlights placed in 2 locations, closer in, beaming across the city and the man.  With more interaction: we’re adding light sabers and a celestial pointing app to beam at interesting objects and aliens.

And big rainbow mirrors too.  (No unicorns, sorry.)

What We Need

We made a huge investment in 2013, and did our debut on the playa.
It’s all built, it works and ready-to-go.
We’re asking for your contribution to bring it back to the playa in 2014 (we're chipping in personally too).
Your contribution will help with:
  • Transport to the playa (freight flatbed $2000 each way - only 2 BM allowed vendors)
  • Load/offload logistics (Hyster rental $580)
  • Generator fuel on playa (4 hrs per night for 7 nights $1108)
  • Generator air filters (playa dust! $88)
  • Searchlight air filters (more playa dust, 2 for each $96)
  • Bits for a few more very cool features ($140)
And we’re always looking for people to join the project:
  • Electrical and software maker type people
  • Mechanics and diesel whisperers
  • Art and performance ideas: what do you want to do with billions of candlepower?

What Just Happened?

Historic military searchlights previously used by NASA to light Apollo and Space Shuttle night launches, now on the playa for art!
It starts from the playa.  A few years back on the playa I (Neal) saw the DeathRay, a fire crew beacon using a 2.2kW army tank searchlight.  I had to have one.  Then made the mistake of asking the seller “what else do you have”...

So I ended up with a collection of military surplus AN/TVS-3 "battlefield illuminators” from the 1960s, and started on the idea of a San Francisco Bay Area performance art installation with searchlights.  Timothy Childs joined the project, amplified the idea and provided warehouse space on Treasure Island.
I got sucked in: restoring 45 year old military hardware (sitting in a field for 25 years), working with high voltage/high current Xenon short-arc bulbs, formulating dielectric coolant, procuring searchlights and 400Hz diesel generators in military surplus auctions.
Jeremy Crandell joined in and made all kinds of things happen.
We ended up with 18 searchlights, 6 diesel generators from 15kW to 96kW, and tons of spare parts.  This is nuts.
For the geeky details check out http://www.candlepowerforums.com/vb/showthread.php?348441-AN-TVS-3-project
Now that the lights worked they had to do something.  So we formed a team including Jon Foote and Rob Gaunt to motorize these old beasts and make them interactive.  We added servo controls and software, built custom trailers.  Monica Wu made our swag.
When we brought it to the playa, Colin Bowring found us and brought his rainbows (photo from GhostShip Halloween).

What You Get

Your help will be huge.
For any contribution you’ll get the satisfaction of seeing beams on the playa at night and being able to say “I helped get those beams here”.
Come out on playa, say hello, interact and get personal appreciation!  We’ll have 2 locations: 2:00 and 10:00 between the man and the Esplanade, and also plan to collaborate with other projects in different locations.
So we’re way, way behind on swag.
  • For $25 you get invited to our next searchlight BBQ, before or after Burningman.
  • For $50 you get a cool long-sleeve T-shirt with a searchlight image and beam that glows in the dark.  We’re hoping to deliver these on playa, maybe.
  • For $1250 you get Project Flashlight at your event (2 lights, 2hrs, San Francisco or Oakland, logistics to be arranged).
The image will be based on this photo by Hap (without the bridge)

story:
Click Here to Learn About Our Rewards Program - Share and Get Money Back!
















What is Scrib?

Scrib is THE absolute stylus that can be used on mobile devices having capacitive screen technology. Scrib replaces your finger when using your mobile device and offers unparalleled precision and the same flexibility in writing and drawing as a normal pen would.

Scrib also comes with its dedicated app for both iOS and Android mobile devices that allows you to transform your handwritten notes into digital text, just as if you were typing. Scrib dedicated app recognizes your handwriting style in more than 50 languages, as well as mathematics and shapes.

As a stylus, Scrib is unprecedented. As an item Scrib is a status symbol made for you!


With which mobile devices is Scrib compatible to?

Scrib works on any mobile device using a capacitive screen.


What purpose do cartridges serve?

Cartridges are the physical embodiment of Scrib’s timeless nature. As Scrib’s body is a piece of timeless elegance, cartridges allow you to adapt to any future need or technological advancement, just by upgrading or replacing the cartridge. With the current cartridges, you can write on any capacitive screen with precision, using the aluminum tip cartridge or design freely with the rubber tips. In the case of iOS 8 where variable touch sizing is present, the rubber tips, due to their footprint, can be used to produce diffrent design effects.


Does Scrib need batteries to work?

No! Scrib is battery independent. Its unique features are the result of advanced engineering and high level of craftsmanship. Nothing electronic requiring batteries is included in Scrib.


Does Scrib require a specific software/app to work?

No! Scrib is software independent. It works on any mobile device without requiring any specific software to be installed. Scrib is is compatible with all touch screens (Smartphones, or Tablets).


How is Scrib different from other stylus in the market?

Trying to compare Scrib with another stylus is like trying to compare a fighter jet to a fisherman’s boat; in a wider sense both are transportation means but... it is self-evident that there can be no direct comparison between the two.

Scrib is far more advanced than any other stylus in the market in terms of engineering.

It is so advanced that it requires 18 processes to be made whereas the most advanced stylus from the bunch requires only 8. This is something that becomes apparent when looking at ergonomics, writing feel, aesthetics, quality and of course the price.

At the end of the day, disregarding features and functions, Scrib is lifestyle and technology forged into a timeless piece of stylus, especially for you.


What does it mean that Scrib is a solution?

Scrib comes with its dedicated app for both iOS and Android tablets that allows you to transform your handwritten notes into digital text, just as if you were typing. Scrib dedicated app recognizes your handwriting style in more than 24 languages, as well as mathematics and shapes. This moves Scrib from being just a stylus to being a complete productivity solution.


If I download the Scrib dedicated app , will I be able to use it with another stylus?

Scrib dedicated app unlocks only by using a code related to each product. This code is different from one Scrib unit to another and is included in the packaging. Anyone can download and install the app but only Scrib owners can use it with one tablet.


I lost my app’s activation code... What now?

Each Scrib is uniquely related to an activation code. In case you loose it, you just contact us. We’ll check your Scrib’s ID and provide you with the missing code.


Extended goal of different colors has been achieved. How do I order a different color?

If you haven’t selected a perk yet, select it and specify the color you want in your email to us. If have already selected your perk, just email us with the color you wish to receive.
